text:
Very unlikely. Thermohaline circulation would probably become slower, but against a backdrop of higher water vapour/energy transport and much increased continental climate average temperatures. 

Northern Canada is a large continental landmass associated with the Greenland Icecap, Europe is a peninsula surrounded by the warm Mediterranean and the Atlantic Ocean, they are not climatically comparable. 

A more likely scenario is a slowly increasing GAT, with Europe experiencing more of an East Coast climate, Winters a little colder but sunnier, with an increased chance of heavy snow fall near the coastlines, and Summers warmer  with shorter spells of localised heavy rain, and annual average temperature increasing moderately across Europe. Flood damage would be more common due to increased pressure on drainage systems. Increased aridity on more Southern coastlines would be expected.

Weaker circulation may slow down the hitherto very rapid loss of polar sea ice and surface water heating, but the blue water summer surface ocean warming combined with warmer air spilling off the North coast of Asia would likely continue the process of strengthening the Arctic warming feedback.

The medieval cooling trend could be correlated with the slow forcing effect of the Earths orbital cycles moving towards a tipping point into a new glacial maximum, although that appears to have been decisively overwhelmed by anthropogenic emissions.

The Younger Dryas event (end of last ‚Äúice age‚Äù) occurred against a backdrop of low global ocean temperature, and in particular extensive volumes of land ice. Neither of these preconditions exist today.

 This year we had an Atlantic high which trapped warm humid air over Western Europe, to a lesser extent than western Canada, which is an unusual pattern here and may be a sign of things to come.

text:
Maybe you should have looked a little further back than just to the 12th century, like the ice ages of the last 450k years, then you would have found that our "unnatural" "man-made" climate change is pretty normal. 400k years, ago, 320k years ago, 230k years ago and finally 120k years ago the climate reached exactly the point we are on at the moment, followed by a warmth period between 5000 and 25000 years that were warmer on average between 3 and 6 degrees than what we are at right now. SO seemingly we have lived back then as well, because if there is no other explanation than man-made climate change today, somehow you have to explain those warmth periods as well. And obviously, it can be 3¬∞-6¬∞ warmer over a period of roughly 20.000 years without the earth exploding or all land being subdued in water. Also, the period of 3¬∞-6¬∞ colder temperatures than today, the so-called ice age, took about 80k years, while the earth warmed up gradually over the course of the last 20k years to today¬¥s values, and this is just average as well. We would expect the temperatures to rise another 3¬∞ to 6¬∞ and stay like this for between 5000 and 25000 years, even if there were no human race at all.

So yes, the climate is changing, it always did and maybe we do speed it up a little, but we couldn't keep the earth from warming another 3-6¬∞ even if we tried because that¬¥s simply what is happening in a pretty normal 80k - 120k year cycle.

I have included a debunking of 'accumulated heat' as it is so often used to explain how trace elements, so called 'greenhouse gasses', can warm the planet. 

Accumulated heat whilst sounding a reasonable explanation of how heat can build up is rather nothing more than gobbledygook. In fact it shows those using such arguments do not even understand what heat is. 

When we measure temperature we are measuring the heat energy a thing is losing. In short heat is a measurement of flow, the transfer of heat energy and this will always be in the direction towards the colder. For this reason a thing can never 'accumulate heat' in the way those advocating CO2 climate change describe. The temperature of a body is the measure of heat output, it can never be greater than the measure of heat input. Output = input. When a thing is warmed it is heated to an equivalent of the heat input. If this input is not maintained it will cool. Those that propose that heat can build up to be hotter than the total measure of heat input at a given time either do not understand what heat is or are being deliberately misleading. To illustrate, an object being heated by a flame can never become hotter than that flame, it's temperature cannot rise inexorably to the temperature of the sun for instance. Heat cannot be accumulated. When we think about it common sense tells us this must be the case. 

NASA and even Nobel Prize winning physicists have expounded 'accumulated heat' as the explanation how CO2 is able to warm the atmosphere. They claim that over hundreds of years CO2 has captured heat energy and this heat has 'accumulated' to produce a serious warming effect. As I have just explained, this is totally impossible and fundamentally violates all the laws of thermodynamics. That respected scientists should support such uneducated, unthinking nonsense is disturbing and only reflects that in terms of being able to think clearly about a subject they have no facility or inclination. These are the Dark Ages of science. Belief has outweighed logic or any critical thought. It tells us that we should not unquestioningly accept anything we are told, that experts can be fools. 

(NB: be aware of attempts to discard thermodynamics by talking about biology. 
Eg. 'It only takes a drop of arsenic to kill a person.'
This would be somewhat desperate, muddled thinking. Clearly biological processes based on the reaction of a cell are not the same as the laws of physics/thermodynamics).

text:
Plants help regulate CO2 levels and produce O2? Good to know, shame we are fucking cutting all of the rainforests down continually reducing the planet's ability to do this.
The only "more life" that I see is insects like mosquitos, last I checked humans have been responsible for entire new extinction event before environment science even became a thing because of how much wildlife we actively hunt down and kill off.

CO2 doesn't need to have been the leading cause in the medieval era either since it isn't the only thing that affects the climate which we already knew about. The problem is that CO2 is the biggest thing we pump into the air, and thanks to things like chemistry  (knowing how CO2 interacts with light and other chemical compounds) and even evidence from ice cores, we know that CO2 does correlate very heavily with global temperature increases.
author: Edelwise

text:
¬†@Edelwise¬† Actually... thanks to things like chemistry, we know that the CO2 absorption spectrum is mostly overlapped by the water's. The water in our atmosphere is the biggest greenhouse gas by FAR. CO2, which is the 2nd, is estimated to participate for like 9-20% I believe? Water is more than 3 times that. Ozone and oxygen absorb the UVs, which neither CO2 nor water do. And CO2 absorbs only a fraction of infrareds and little else... infrareds which do not carry much energy, light nor heat compared to the visible and UV spectrums.

CO2 levels on Earth used to be more than times the amount they were at the past century. Yet the temperature wasn't that much higher. That didn't stop an Ice Age from happening in the middle of warmer climate. What it DID do however is help provoke the BIGGEST explosion of life on our planet. Because carbon is the source of most life on Earth. Plants need it, we need it (cf carbohydrates, etc), animals need it... Greenhouses pump CO2 inside for a reason. It gives them much better yields in terms of quantity, quality and volume, time... as well as allowing the plants to be more resilient to diseases.

However, you are correct in one thing: it's not the only thing that affects climate. CO2 barely affects climate in fact. Solar activity however, now that is a game changer. Look up articles on why we got massive a heat spike in the 1920s that lasted 2-3 decades, before going back to our regular, cooler weather. That wasn't CO2, it was crazy low at the time. It was all solar activity.
author: Ninjaed

text:
¬†@Ninjaed¬† "Actually... thanks to things like chemistry, we know that the CO2 absorption spectrum is mostly overlapped by the water's. The water in our atmosphere is the biggest greenhouse gas by FAR. CO2, which is the 2nd, is estimated to participate for like 9-20% I believe?"

5ppm water vapour in the atmosphere which we're also helping to increase. Your point being?

"CO2 levels on Earth used to be more than times the amount they were at the past century."

Takes a single google search, 100 years ago CO2 levels were 200ppm lower, bit over a half of what it is now. The last time CO2 levels were at a similar level it was 100,000 years ago correlating with a global temperature increase similar to what we experience today. Issue is that in our times the CO2 levels will continue to rise and even accelerate unless we take action.

"That didn't stop an Ice Age from happening in the middle of warmer climate."
Have you watched this video? It describes the mechanics of how a warmer period can lead to an ice age.

"What it DID do however is help provoke the BIGGEST explosion of life on our planet."
Right after killing a lot of it off, which could be us too.

"Solar activity however, now that is a game changer."
Also factually wrong, Takes a single google search as well. Temperatures are rapidly climbing for the past 80 years when Sun's irradiance has gotten weaker.
Any effect the Sun has on our atmosphere we're completely overriding with the amount of greenhouse gasses we pump into the atmosphere. If you were right we'd be experiencing the global temperatures dropping right now when the complete opposite is true.

"Look up articles on why we got massive a heat spike in the 1920s that lasted 2-3 decades, before going back to our regular, cooler weather. That wasn't CO2, it was crazy low at the time. It was all solar activity."

1920s temperatures have been overtaken by 1970s and it's been rising since then and again, the solar irradiance has only gotten weaker. Furthermore since 1920 we have increased CO2 levels by 50%.
author: Edelwise

text:
¬†@Edelwise¬† "What it DID do however is help provoke the BIGGEST explosion of life on our planet."
Right after killing a lot of it off, which could be us too.

... The Ice Age happened millions of years after that, not before that. Well, "the" Ice Age. One Ice Age, really.
And these were the times when CO2 levels being several times higher than they've been the past century. I wasn't saying that CO2 levels in the past century were higher than they are today.

Besides, you say that solar activity is factually not as important? Do you even know what the greenhouse effect is? It's when gases are KEEPING sunlight inside. In other words, it boils down to solar activity. Now assuming you're correct, that'd mean temperatures are steadily increasing over the year (since heat would be trapped)... yet facts show otherwise, since we've had record cold winters and all. You can bring the video again if you want, but then I'll point out that the Earth hasn't been in a constant Ice Age with higher CO2 levels. That kinda debunks that theory already, unless it's a cycle. But then... we'd either be going toward a tropical age or an ice age. We can't go for both at the same time, and the data you've been using shows a warming, not a cooling despite those record cold winters. Something simply doesn't add up.

As for the rest, I'll just say there's been fraud in order to push the global warming agenda. Check a curb of CO2 levels rising over the past 100 years. They've been rising consistently, right? Then check which year summits happened in and label those years on that graph. Yep, they didn't do ANYTHING. A far cry from how fast and efficiently they reacted to the ozone layer hole. We can talk about everything else, but if it really were an issue, they'd have done something already. Instead, for more than 50 years, they've done... close to nothing. Odd that they'd react so differently to 2 similar issues, no?

There's too much to cover anyway and I know in your place, I wouldn't be convinced by me. So all I can ask is that you check people who seriously discuss the counter-arguments. Always researrch all sides of an issue before coming to a conclusion, otherwise bias will heavily play and skew perception of it.
author: Ninjaed

text:
¬†@Ninjaed¬† Are you seriously implying that my argument is that the sun plays no role?
I don't know who you're trying to make an idiot out of, me or yourself.

Of course the sun does have an effect, BUT the Sun isn't the direct cause of the Contemporary global temperature increase. If it were the temperatures would be now dropping, which they don't. Something CLEARLY is causing the planet to become hotter DESPITE the sun's low irradiance. I wonder what considering it overlaps perfectly with human activity on earth.
author: Edelwise

text:
¬†@Ninjaed¬† Furthermore you don't and you can't argue against the fact that global warming DOESN'T mean steady increase of temperature all over the globe. That's not how Earth works.
It can cause change in the oceanic and atmospheric currents which cause record winters wherever you live. Doesn't change the fact that the global temperature does in fact increase.
And for your record winters I have my own record winters too where within 10 years we went from routine of -15C 1m of snowfall to average 5C and completely snow less winters for many years in a row.
author: Edelwise

text:
¬†@Edelwise¬† Well look at that, according to you we have record winters with low solar activity. How exactly is it warming again? Not trying to make an idiot out of anyone, that's your assumption... which now urges me to assume your aim was to make an idiot of me to make yourself look smart. So thanks for that and ignoring the part where I said to just look at all sides of the argument on your own because we both know you won't be convinced by anything I say anyway.

Then you're telling me global warming is causing record low temperatures... but it's still warming! Okay, maybe there's a massive fall in temperature in winter and the average is still increasing... but that's not what's happening, is it? In Canada, snow came earlier and melted later than usual. Their winter lasted longer because temperatures were lower than usual over the months. Even in the UK, they got some summer hail in June. Definitely not warmer over the year. In fact, one article states this:
"With this all being said, the UK Met Office scientists are forecasting that 2021 will be a little cooler around the world and this means that we may not be in for a long, warm, and bumper summer that we would hope for after a long and cold winter. As we all know, this current spring season certainly has not been a record-breaker for warmth!"

Now they do say the trend is still upward, but there has yet to be (in the US for instance) massive droughts like there has been in the 1920s when millions of people died, crops burnt, animals fell dead and more. Yet temperatures in the 1970s were higher than those in the 1920s during a period of drought which saw millions of people die? Really?

Also fine, if global warming doesn't mean a steady increase of temperature over the world, what exactly does it mean? Can you define it? Because unless my English is rusty, "global" means "everywhere" and "warming" means higher temperature. And of course, the concept is talking about a trend. Otherwise, it's just summer or a heatwave. So... what does "global warming" mean exactly? We can't really keep discussing it unless we actually both know what we're discussing.
author: Ninjaed

text:
¬†@Ninjaed¬† "How is it warming again?"
By measuring the global average?
Really complicated, I know.
author: Edelwise

text:
¬†@Edelwise¬† The global average is, as I pointed out, cooler this year. Not warming.

Also, when talking about climate, you look at the weather over an extended period of time. There were 2 droughts spanning a century or so over the past thousand of years. For people back then, that's all they'd have known. The "climate" would have been normal for them even over their entire lifespan... yet it actually was a long period of drought.

Knowing this, it becomes very easy to misinform over "climate change". The world was, after the drought of the 1920s, in a wetter, cooler period. In other words, temperatures were below average. Recently, they have begun to rise slightly. What evidence is there that it's not natural and is tied to human influence? There's pretty much only one (now that the ozone layer hole has been fixed), CO2. But that theory doesn't add up to the cooler year we're having and other stuff we've already discussed. The CO2 levels were lower during the 1920s drought. Since then there's nee, more and more CO2. It would stand to reason temperature would keep rising and rising... yet it didn't, as our record cold temperatures have shown.

GLOBAL WARMING DOESN'T MEAN GRADUAL WARMING OF THE SUFRACE AT EVERY PLACE IN THE WORLD. CLIMATE IS NOT AS EASY AS YOU'D WANT IT TO BE.

BUT, IF YOU LOOK AT THE TREND, TEMPERATURE KEEPS ON CLIMBING OVER PAST FEW DECADES. DO YOU KNOW  WHAT A TREND IS?

"What evidence is there that it's not natural and is tied to human influence?"
Because we know how CO2 works and it alligns perfectly with human activity?
Feels like I could spit in your face and you'd ponder "I wonder what evidence there is that a human spat on my face, maybe in reality it's just raining?"

That theory doesn't add up with your ignorance on climate mechanics, at most.

"The CO2 levels were lower during the 1920s drought."
True, and now the solar irradiance is lower than it was during the 1950s colder period and yet, the temperature is climbing. I guess it's just magic and there's no a single possibility that humans need to take any kind of responsibility.

"Since then there's nee, more and more CO2. It would stand to reason temperature would keep rising and rising... yet it didn't, as our record cold temperatures have shown."

Do yourself and myself a favour and watchi this video you're commenting on, again, I told you to do it in the past I think and you seem to need to rewatch it again.

author: Edelwise

text:
¬†@Edelwise¬† Why are you so vindictive, seriously? Can't you have a proper discussion without blowing out in anger, insulting others? Sheesh.

Anyway, I asked you to define "global warming" and all you told me is "it's not as simple as you think". That's... cool I guess? Not a definition though. If you yourself can't define it, you can make it say whatever the hell you want and it'll be correct, because you can skew the definition to encompass what you want. Just like how the definition of harrassment has changed so much that it's lost the "repeatingly" part of its definition and the line not to cross is now "don't talk to me, don't look at me... unless you're handsome, then it's cool". So you can talk once to a girl and you're sued for harrassment. It happened. So again, what's the definition of global warming?

Then I tell you the global average is cooler, you say "but it's warmer in some parts"!! ... Okay? So when it's warmer, can I say "but it's cooler in some parts"? That's actually an argument you thought I made (with those record cold winters) and back then, you said "it doesn't matter, the average is warmer"! So which is it? You see why having a definition is important? I'm not going to dance with you when you can dictate the rules you want when you want.

You said the 1920s were getting warmer, though there were fluctuations. Indeed. So? Have I ever denied that it's getting warmer? No, in fact I even pointed out that temperatures before were below the average. Yet when you start a graph at those low temperatures, it looks like a rapid, steady rise. That's plain lying and is what the media and government love to do to push that agenda. In reality, we're entering a period of drought, be it short or long, so temperatures will be higher than the average... then after the drought, it'll be back to lower temperatures. That's how climate works, but surely you know that? Since you've been talking down to me at every turn you could about how I don't get it but you do?

You say solar irradiance is decreasing but temperature isn't. Guess what? That's not the first time in history that would've happened. Sometimes it's also much higher and doesn't fully impact temperature. There are other important things to take into consideration; despite it being the main driving force, it's not the only one. Also, depending on the source you're looking at at, solar irradiance is actually increasing. Like NASA, where we're on the upwards trend of its cycle. Huh.

Anyway, I'm getting tired of your bouts of anger. I'll just say this: yes CO2 provokes rising temprature, but it's so much more than that. It also has a role as feedback on top of its role of driving climate. In other words, it both drives climate and is driven by climate.
However, the scope of it all is another thing entirely. Will it be enough to have a major impact other than 2 degrees more across the globe? What about the coming Ice Age? Like you said, solar irradiation is on the decline, which would lead to an ice age with low CO2 levels. But if CO2 levels are high enough, the ice age will be avoided instead.

There's so much more, a lot of which neither you or I have any expertise on. So all that remains to be said is this: 2/3 of CO2 emissions are China alone. Their emissions have only ever increased over the past century, no summit ever changed that. If global warming is a concern, shouldn't THAT be a priority instead of guiltying common folks about turning on their AC? Food for thought...
author: Ninjaed

text:
¬†@Ninjaed¬† "Why are you so vindictive, seriously? Can't you have a proper discussion without blowing out in anger, insulting others? Sheesh."

"Not a definition though. If you yourself can't define it, you can make it say whatever the hell you want and it'll be correct, because you can skew the definition to encompass what you want."

Global warming is when there is a continuous many year long upward trend of the global temperature.

It is cooler, for one year, during a 50 year long upward trend.
It's actually me who should be saying "Then I tell you the global average is rising, you say <<but it's a little cooler this year and there's been a few cold winters in some places>>!!... Okay?"

Just because there is 1 cooler year in a series of a dozen when it was steadily climbing doesn't mean the global warming had stopped or that those dozen warmer years didn't happen at all.

"That's actually an argument you thought I made (with those record cold winters) and back then, you said "it doesn't matter, the average is warmer"! So which is it?"
Yes because that's exactly the argument you make, an anecdote about some single region having colder winters, so I gave you a counter anecdote which I'm experiencing firsthand and have been experiencing it over the past decade or so and now you're having problems with anecdotes? Apparently it's only bad when they can be used against your position, lol.

"You said the 1920s were getting warmer, though there were fluctuations. Indeed. So?"
So why the fuck are you surprised that there are fluctuations NOW? THINK.

"In reality, we're entering a period of drought, be it short or long, so temperatures will be higher than the average..."
Yeah tell that to all the people in the tropics with record amount of hurricanes. They sure are dying of draught.
Draughts are only local, not global, unless it's some catastrophic event.

Furthermore you're basing a sun irradiance caused warmer period and apply the same logic to this one which ISN'T caused by the irradiance. Will it eventually lead to a colder period? Sure it will, watch the video again. You must've watched it 5 times by now from me telling you to rewatch it and you still fail to grasp what this video is trying to explain. Cold climate will come around at some point, but it won't be pleasant for humanity leading up to that point or when the ice age comes.

"Since you've been talking down to me at every turn you could about how I don't get it but you do?"
I'm sorry you tried to "get back" at me? If you could point out the attempt for me please do because all I can see is some dude whining.

 "You say solar irradiance is decreasing but temperature isn't. Guess what? That's not the first time in history that would've happened. Sometimes it's also much higher and doesn't fully impact temperature."
So why in the fuck were you even mentioning it in the first place and wasting my fucking time?
Is that your thing you get off to? Saying completely pointless shit to waste others' time? Maybe because unless you try for this attention on the internet nobody is willing to give any to you in real life?

"Also, depending on the source you're looking at at, solar irradiance is actually increasing. Like NASA, where we're on the upwards trend of its cycle. Huh."
Do me a favour and look at the last 100 years of this irradiance and then think again, if you can. Then plot on that graph global temperatures. Then think very very very hard on it, spend a week staring at it if you need to, then get back to me and apologize for being a lowly idiot.

"However, the scope of it all is another thing entirely. Will it be enough to have a major impact other than 2 degrees more across the globe? What about the coming Ice Age?"

The Ice Age that we're actively putting back in time with our CO2 output?
You won't be able to experience it and neither will your kids. But hopefully some descendant of yours, if someone is unlucky enough to have your kids, that is, will be able to reach that point and survive that test for humanity as well, that's assuming we don't drive the climate off the cliff and cause another mass extinction event which will impact us greatly.

"Like you said, solar irradiation is on the decline, which would lead to an ice age with low CO2 levels. But if CO2 levels are high enough, the ice age will be avoided instead."
Watch this video again, watch it 10 times, also please write down in the comment the full text of this video from speech to text so I know you've listened to it.

"There's so much more, a lot of which neither you or I have any expertise on. So all that remains to be said is this: 2/3 of CO2 emissions are China alone. Their emissions have only ever increased over the past century, no summit ever changed that. If global warming is a concern, shouldn't THAT be a priority instead of guiltying common folks about turning on their AC? Food for thought..."

China is a lot more concerned with its selfish megalomania of becoming the world largest superpower to care about the climate, but I want to think that once they realize that they're playing a dead man's game they will fix their shit.

text:
In English taking and bringing have a different tense, analogous  to time we use "have and had",  but in the case of "take and bring" it's based on the location and who is speaking and the tense of the person who is asking or speaking.

For example:  
When you say I will be bring my clothes to Europe, the tense is grammatically incorrect and would be like saying: 

"I hope you have a pleasant visit to Europe last year". Notice how strange that sounds?
vs
"I hope you had a pleasant visit to Europe last year"  


Unlike "have and had" which tense is based on time, "bring and take" tense is based on location of the person who is either speaking or making the request. 

When do I use bring?

You use bring when you ask someone to bring you something to your location, i.e. The location of the person your making the request is in a different location than the requestor, even if its in the same room and they are to bring the tv remote from their location to your location. Notice bring is used when the item is in the other location.

Example: "Can you bring your clothes with you to Europe", when asked by someone who is in the location of the request. i.e. Europe.

When do I use Take?

Either if you are taking something from your location, or asking someone to take something from your location to another location. Notice take is used if the item is in your location.

Example: "Can you take your clothes with you to Europe" or "I will take my clothes to Europe" this states that I will take the clothes from my location to the other location.

I hope this makes Tense! Enjoy!!

Please spread the word of the grammatical use of Bring and Take, it makes individuals sound some what uneducated and I know that's not what they want to sound like.

Well there is something to precise. On earth eastern parts of high latitudes oceans are warmers than their western equivalant, it is not a feature of Europe, further, Europe looks like a huge peninsula such as Alaska and this could play also a role. But again you forgot to explain one point : what is the link between sea and air temperature? If you take the Kalahari region, it is one of the hottest and it faces a cold part of the Atlantic Ocean. The same goes for South Chili. The point is scientists are not sure that it is the gulf stream that controls the European temperature or if gulf stream and Europe temperature are both controlled by something : the easterly wind. This is probably what gives the mild European temperature, or at least contribute to it.
If the gulf stream stops but the easterly remains the first consequence to occur should be a drier Europe because cold ocean means less evaporation and therefore less cloud/rain. To generate a cold age you need more parameters including the sun activity and earth precession. Now, the north hemisphere is pointing at the sun (summer) when the planet is the further away from it and winter for the closest, creating mild temperatures. This is the opposite for the south hemisphere but since it does not have huge pass lands, it does not matter. However it has been shown that this orientation evolves with time and when the north hemisphere points toward the sun whilst the planet is closed to the sun, it creates light exposure and since the north has more land mass this results in extreme seasons. And when this major change coincides with other changes such as reduction of sun power or reduction of the gulf stream, extreme climate (hot summer and cold winter) turns to mild summer and cold winter in the north driving an  ice age.

text:
Scientific theories have never been established by consensus. Science is validated by comparing observations or experiments with theories. If the facts agree with the theory, confidence in the theory grows. If the facts contradict the theory, the theory is abandoned or modified and retested. Again and again, key predictions of alarming climate models have disagreed with observations and have greatly exaggerated supposedly harmful effects from more CO2.

CO2 is not a pollutant
'To suddenly label CO2 as a "pollutant" is a disservice to a gas that has played an enormous role in the development and sustainability of all life on this wonderful Earth. Mother Earth has clearly ruled that CO2 is not a pollutant.' (Robert Balling, as quoted by Popular Technology). As measured from space, the whole earth is getting greener as a result of Carbon Dioxide. CO2 is increasing agricultural yields, it is increasing the forest, it is increasing the growth in the biological world and that‚Äôs important and more certain then the effects on climate which is almost nonexistent.
Climate changes because of circulation patterns caused by Solar activity ( changes in irradiance, Magnet Field, absorption in the stratosphere, Cosmic rays modulation) and the stages of the moon. The earth rotating around the sun in a elliptical pattern has multiple fluctuations and variances on the years since its existence. The earths elliptical pattern causes the earth to get closer to the sun (80 million  miles) and farther away from the sun (116 million miles). The earth spins (wobbling a 26,000 year cycle between Polaris and Vega) around the sun at a tilt (varies from 22.1 to 24.5 degrees) which is not constant and varies over time. This tilt also effects earth's climate. (Milankovitch Theory). Man does not have the ability to change circulation patterns. Temperatures changes has nothing to do with CO2. You can not control CO2 (you breath out CO2 (40,000 ppm) plant food). CO2 can never be a air pollutant ( 2 USA supreme court judges) The weather Climate system is powered by solar energy. The Total solar irradiance (W/m2) (temperature) data matches very well with Northern Hemisphere temperatures. Compare Total solar irradiance (W/m2) vs Total Water Vapour matching very good. 
Climate has being changing for 4.5 billion years. Climate change is nothing that you have to prove, it is always changing. Making Climate change into something that is alarming, which governments are doing is weird and irresponsible and devious. The questions to ask is what is a normal climate on this earth? What should be the normal average mean Temperature on this planet? The average temperature on the suns surface is about 6,000 degrees Celsius and the suns core temperature is 17 million degrees Celsius. The temperature on earth during the Maunder Minimum and the irradiance will decrease by 0.3%. The average Temperatures in England will decrease by 0.8 degrees Celsius. This could last for 11 years of lower temperatures that will result in world wide poor food productivity which cause lead to food shortages and the problems that goes with it. (Valentina Zharkova Sun EXPERT)
Professor Valentina Zharkova predicts the modern Grand Minimum to occur from 2020 to 2055
(In 2019 snow on July 7,12 and 14 in the Carpathian Mountains in Romania & Hungary first time in 150 years. In North America cooler and wetter weather have caused poor crop yields and problem getting crops off the fields. Then there was about 1 meter high hail stones falling in Mexico. Biologists from Greece & meteorologist from Finland have noticed that vegetation/bushes/trees are one month late, nature starting to feel the effects of the solar Magnetic field is decreasing.)
Temperatures will be dropping that may have food shortages (both for animals & humans) starting 2028 to 2032. The world only has the capability to feed the planet for 60 days before we need to grow more food.


The difference between weather and climate is a measure of time. Weather is  what conditions of the atmosphere are over a short period of time, and climate is how the atmosphere "behaves" over relatively long periods of time.
 Carbon Dioxide absorption is logarithmic NOT Linear. CO2 will only absorb radiation at a certain wavelength 15 micron.
Greenhouse gas system:
95% is water vapour
3.6% is Carbon Dioxide which consists of 
Natural occurring CO2 is 3.48%
Man made CO2 is 0.12%
Canada produces only 1.6% of the world's CO2 emissions.
The atmosphere consist of 0.040%
Water Vapour (which causes 95% of greenhouse warming has not increased)
Since the 1950, CO2 increased by 0.008% (during the warming period 1980 to 2000 not enough to cause any significant warming)
Carbon Dioxide has no significant effect on global temperature.
Cutting Carbon Dioxide emissions will not change atmospheric CO2.
CO2 always lags global warming so it can NOT be the cause of Global warming.
There is NO correlation between CO2 and temperature increases.
Many hundreds / thousands of global warming events have occurred over geological past BEFORE the rise of CO2 and thus could NOT be cause by CO2.
Only 0.1% of the global warming period correlates with increased CO2.

text:
This was a fine video with one salient exception.  Most of the explanation of thermohaline circulation is excellent, it all makes perfect sense, except for the very beginning.  Shortly before 4:00 the video notes that the equitorial waters are more dense due to increased salinity.   Thermohaline circulation relies on this density, as water falling down from the surface pushes the other water out of the way, starting the circulation.  All fine.  But the video also says that the warm equitorial waters do not sink because they are warm.  This is also logical.  But then the video goes on to talk about what happens to these warm, saline waters as they begin to move north in the Gulf Stream.  Except . . . what is it that impels the Gulf Stream to move at all?  The video tells us that the warm, salty equitorial waters simply start moving north.  Why?  How?

I'm not questioning the science here.  I'm just saying there was a gap in the narrative.  At least I think there was; I'll be happy to be corrected.

text: Yes. Obliquity is the big item of the 3 items. When Earth has its least tilt is when conditions favour a glaciation period (colloquial "ice age") because then the SUMMERS at latitude 65N can't get warm enough to melt 100% of the snow from the previous winter there so it builds up year over year, century over century. The last ~1,000,000 years though CO2 got so low at 280 ppmv that obliquity (tilt) by itself wasn't enough to pull the northern hemisphere completely out of a glaciation period so it needed both precession and the 100,000 / 400,000 year orbital ellipticity cycles to give it that final push of warming at latitude 65N so that's why the cycle length increased ~1,000,000 years ago from the old 40,000-year tilt "mini glaciation" cycles of a few million years ago to the recent (last ~1,000,000 years) ~110,000-year "full glaciation" cycles with the 3 of ~26,000-year partial de-glaciation (ice sheets retreated a huge amount and then advanced again) that you clearly see in the Greenland ice core proxy surface temperature analysis plot. Note: I'm not checking my memory for accuracy of the time scales above unless somebody says they're interested, or tells me themself, because ~nobody reads, studies & understands my science comments in the GoogleTubes venue because it's a >99.9% fast-stupid-babble venue.

text:
Ok, I have to interject here.because you are leaving out a lot of very important facts. First off, it has been well established, and even agreed to by the UN scientists that the carbon dioxide percentage in the atmosphere is around 0.4%, and of that 0.4% carbon dioxide, humans produce approximately 3% while the other 97% is produced by nature. Everyone believes that plants take in carbon dioxide and release oxygen through a process called photosynthesis, and yes, that is true during the daytime, but at night the exact opposite happens. Plants around the world take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide through a process called respiration. Humans are not the only, or even the largest producers of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere each year, in fact, we only provide a very small portion of it.

Secondly, the main factor that leads to cyclic heating and cooling of the Earth is not carbon dioxide, ocean salinity, or any other factor here on Earth, it is the Sun, and solar cycles, which the UN scientists are just not finally realizing. The Earth has been heating up and cooling down in cycles for millions of years, LONG before humans were ever on the planet. So, if humans were not here yet to cause ‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù, how did it happen over and over again?

text:
NO global warming will not be the cause of a new ice age. But the Earths orbit around the sun and the suns fluctuating energy output could and most likely will cause the earth to cool rapidly sooner or later.
The sun is not a constant and neither is our orbit around it. Combine the 2 and you get hotter and cooler periods. The actual cause of global warming. Yes Yes particulates and gasses do effect global warming and are contributors to retaining the heat effectively being an insulator and yes the evidence suggests water density is a large contributing factor. But the heat is coming from the sun and our molten iron core. 
Check out the new data regarding magnetic fields interacting between the sun and the earth and look at how the suns induction effect heats our iron core. Add that to your model and see how that effects the predicted outcomes.
We have a chilly period coming no doubt and humans will have no control over that. Even if we clean up all the mess from the industrial revolution (something we should be doing anyway) and plant billions of trees to re hydrate the earths surface and force rain fall into the aquafers it will only decrease the effect of the change. We cannot stop it happening.
You show me how to control a massive nuclear reaction that has been burning for well over 4 billion years and I will show you how to stop global warming. Until then just plan for the worst and hope for the best. just like humans have been doing since we became humans as we know them today. We are not Gods we cannot control the forces of the universe on a solar system wide scale. At best we can predict outcomes and plan ahead. 
The fact of the matter is that humans are not that powerful and even with all our combined knowledge and technical skills we still do not understand how even the most basic functions of our own solar system can be altered by us in any significant way. Hell we still do not have a functional single stage to orbit engine yet let alone the ability to effect the suns energy output.

text: its junk science like this that makes me doubtful of much of climate alarmism . he failed to even mention the two most important things driving the Gulf Stream . I don't know if this is because of ignorance or deliberate . the Gulf Stream is powered by the trade winds . the trade winds blow nonstop the same direction  every day of the year in the tropics driving the entire ocean westward .were it not for the americas it would keep going . or if it had an opening to the pacific . the Atlantic Ocean is actually several feet higher in the western Atlantic than it is off Africa ! the reason the GS curves clockwise and travels north up the American coast is because of the Coriolis force which steers all atmospheric and ocean currents . the Gulf Stream is the strongest ocean current in the world and moves at several miles per hour ( depending on where it is measured )  while those thermohaline currents move at several miles a Millenia ! and that maelstrom pic is 100% bull ! there is nothing remotely like this caused by thermohaline currents . this is likely one of several reversing tidal bores . and I have to think the guy who made this knows that . you are being thoroughly and dishonestly manipulated by this video . there is  one oceanographer who has been making actual empirical measurements of Gulf Stream velocities for more than twenty years ( Thomas Rossby , google him ) and he says that stories about the gulf stream slowing down are total nonsense .

text:
It is Impossible to "Start a new Ice Age" when the planet is already in one.   We have been in an ice age for 2.58 million years already.  Its called the Pleistocene, and it is still going strong.  In fact, the next glaciation cycle is about to repeat itself again, in the very near future.  We are currently in an Inter-glacial, known as the Holocene.  
What you are referring to is the repeating glaciation phases that have repeated themselves about every 110,000 years.  If you look back at the past several hundred years, the last Grand Solar Minimum(little ice age) was 440 years ago, called the Maunder Minimum.  
I don't know why this is all so hard for science to work through.  As a physical anthropologist, I have known all this since the mid-70s, as a graduate student.  
1. We are in an ice age - Pleistocene
2.We are currently in an inter-glacial - Holocene
3. We are at the tail end of this inter-glacial, and soon to drop into the next glaciation phase, probably within the next 1-2 hundred years.  Enjoy all this warmth while you can. 
The Last 450,000 years - https://geology.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/ice_ages2.gif
The latest Global Warming Craziness - https://external-content.duckduckgo.com/iu/?u=https%3A%2F%2Fimgpile.com%2Fimages%2F11USgu.jpg&f=1&nofb=1

text:
Global temperature and sea level rise has been accelerating for the past century. The average rate of sea level rise has been increasing. You can obviously see on graphs from 1880 to now that the slope has been getting steeper and steeper.

 https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-global-sea-level

Taking it from the graph 
From 1880 to 1920 -1.3mm/yr
1920 to 1960 - 1.6mm/yr
1960 to 2000 - 1.5mm/yr
1980 to 2020 - 2.6mm/yr
(2000 to 2020 - 3.5mm/yr)

Global temperatures are also accelerating. 
1880 to 1920 - -0.004C/yr
1920 to 1960 - 0.007C/yr
1960 to 2000 - 0.011C/yr
1980 to 2020 - 0.018C/yr
(2000 to 2020 - 0.025C/yr)

Looking at only the 4 decade intervals, we can see that there is acceleration.

https://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/global-temperature/

text:
1. He was referring to Atlantic Canada, not Western Canada. The latitude if London in eastern Canada would be considered northern. 

Also many computer models were accurate.

Hansen et al., 1981 
Predicted a rise if 0.65C from 1981 to 2017 (latest year with data presented on website). In reality 2017 was about 0.75C warmer than ~1980.
1988 Hansen et al. 
Predicted a rise of temps of 0.9C by 2017. Reality was 0.75C. This is because he predicted an increased use of halocarbons, which were mostly banned by the Montreal Protocol. This is why the prediction was higher. The prediction of CO2 concentrations was very similar to what was observed.
IPCC 1990 first assessment
Predicted a mean of 0.84C rise, when in reality is was 0.75. However this was within the margin of error.
IPCC 1995 2and assessment 
Predicted a rise if 0.55C. In reality it was 0.75. This is means the projection actually underestimated global warming.
IPCC 2001 third assessment
Projected a 0.62C rise, which again underestimated the warming observed.

As you can see, many projections that accounted for a rise in CO2 concentrations found that we were to expect warming, which is what we observed.

https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-how-well-have-climate-models-projected-global-warming

text:
No one believes in climate change more than me.  #AlGore and #BillNye are climate change deniers compare to me. 
However Anthropogenic global warming is a hoax. 
Anthropogenic climate change is complete nonsense. 

Carbon dioxide is trace levels in your atmosphere at 400 ppm. 
Furthermore, it only holds heat for a few seconds. Therefore CO2 is not the thermostat that controls our climate on this planet. Carbon dioxide is completely ineffective at driving Climate. 

History even records climate change... we all have seen climate change from 
the three major Ice-ages recorded in history to the subsequent warming 
periods (which were the Medieval warming period in the Roman warming period). 

However, Anthropogenic global warming is a complete hoax. CO2 
has nothing to do with creating global warming. CO2 Is currently 400 ppm. 
That is one carbon-dioxide molecule for every 2500 parts of the atmosphere. 
Humans contribute only a scant 16 ppm which is 4% of the total CO2 produced in a year. 

CO2 only holds heat for a few seconds and there is not enough to drive climate- it is thermodynamically impossible and yet we are told it is true. Lastly, CO2will increase only after temperatures rise and conversely CO2 levels drop as temperatures cool. In other words, CO2 levels are influenced by heat or the lack there of and therefore does not drive climate but follow climate.  #CLIMATECHANGE 

https://youtu.be/7PQRGMn6HG4

text:
The Laurentide Ice Sheet that used to cover all of Canada, the Great Lakes area and surrounding states started receding 10,000 years ago to where it is now. So we can deduce that global warming we know of today, started 10,000 years ago as part of nature's climate change and NOT from increased carbon dioxide emissions. Carbon dioxide (Co2), in turn is a major ingredient for life to exist. Trees for example uses Co2 to survive. Trees takes carbon from Co2 from the air through their leaves and brings carbon down to the ground to its roots and feeds the tree.

Other living things require carbon dioxide to live. Without it, life as we know it, would not exist.

text:
You lost all credibility when you claimed humans are responsible for global warming. Humans are as responsible for gloval warming as ants and spiders are responsible for warming your basement. 
One Volcanic eruption teleases more "greenhouse" gasses than man has in the last 5,000 years.
Gloval warming and cooling are a natural event/cycle. Human activity has less than zero effect on the cycle.
In answer to your question "can global warming lead to a new iceage?" The answer is "yes".
The evidence so far indicates there was a period of global warming just prior to every iceage. Considering the fact tbat humans and industrialization were not around prior to any of the ice ages (there has been more than one) kinda shoots holes in the "humans are responsible" bull shit.
Prior to the 1700's and long before "the industrial revolution", people were ice scating on the Thames River until it stopped freezing over in the late 1700's/early 1800's, again, long before the industrial revolution.
Global Warming is "old news", its been happeninh for hundreds of years.
When (not "if") the Gulf Stream stops or slows enough, there will be another iceage, which will last until the Gulf Stream starts flowing again. Just like every iceage before.
Shore lines will receed, not raise. Who knows? Maybe Florida and Cuba will be connected by dry land again, and the Mediterranean Sea will once again be cut off from the Atlantic, and evaporate to the point it no longer exists again. Sea Levels will drop enough the English Channel will be dry, connecting Britian to France.
Alaska and Russia will again have a "land bridge" connecting them. üò∑ 
Will the shorelines be tbe same after the next iceage? Who inows? I don't. I kinda doubt they will be. The San Andreas Fault may finally have "The Big One" during tbe iceage, and California might be an island or sea bottom as far inland as Nevada and Utah, to the east, and Oregon to the north, when the new iceage is over. (not a "big loss", IMHO. California is lower/worse than "the pits".)

The Barents Sea has already become warmer and more saline.

text: As you are considering your first trip to Europe I would mention my last one. This is in light of exactly what you are describing here, but on a smaller than global scale. I traveled in august 2003 to southern Germany near Lake Constance, or Bodensee as the Germans refer to it. Like you mentioned, I packed light, especially as the news from France a week before I traveled was of old people dying from an especially warm August. Was I surprised to find I was ill equipped for the weather  during my week in Friedrichshaven. While layering my sweater and windbreaker worked for the dry days as a spectator/course marshal for a bicycle sporting event held there in conjunction with a Grand Bicycle  Dealers show at the Messe(Convention center).  When it rained I was shivering and wet as if it were October. Pack a jacket, I would advise. Returning I looked up the reasons for the great disparity in the two week period, and I remember that there was a short shift in the gulf stream that caused that wild swing in temperature.

text: From the authoritative knowledge I gained in my intro to climatology class, I would argue that global warming cannot start a "new ice age" because an ice age is a period of GLOBAL LOW temperatures. Great video though, and a very important topic!

text: The little ice age is tied to volcanism, Kraketau is the main culprit but there were other volcanic events.  As the sun light was blocked and temperatures plummet, it cause a large advance of ice.  There was not a disruption in the oceanic convection as claimed here.  The cause was clearly not how warm the temperatures were preceding the climate change.  This video is misleading and seems to support the theory that industrialization and global warming will cause an ice age.  Though there could be some truth provided the oceanic convection is disrupted, it still may not reverse the parts per million of Co2 in the air to plummet the planet into a major ice age if we keep pumping these gases into the atmosphere.  Climate is more on the geologic timeline than this video would have you believe.  It is more likely the rest of human history will know this warm period to our extinction.  But the planet will be fine, it will eventually shed us as we do an infection, heat it to death.  There will be more ice ages, we may not be alive to see it as a species.

text:
For thinking people; ah, the great debate on climate change. 

One way to test whether this is an honest exchange of facts and ideas is to to seed these sites with facts and ideas that either support the narrative, or contest it.  I have done this over the last week on at least forty of the major taking one side or  the other.  

What I found is that usually within 48 hours, anything I say that doesn't support global warming as a crisis is removed, or edited down to only language that is supportive, while anything  post that would support the argument stays.  Makes one wonder where the money is coming from...

From NASA:¬† Based on orbital variations, Milankovitch predicted that the¬†ice age¬†would peak every 100,000 and 41,000 years, with additional ‚Äúblips‚Äù every 19,000 to 23,000 years. Three variables of the Earth's orbit‚Äîeccentricity, obliquity, and¬†‚Äîaffect global climate. But it's a lot more complicated than that.  

And, the last ice age was about 30,000 years ago. Interestingly humans didn't do so well because it's hard to migrate and one can show that there were less than 30,000 humans that survived through mitochondrial DNA analysis.  Whales, insects and such do much better and have been doing so for 100's of millions of years.

So, I totally believe in climate change... It's been going on for 100's of millions of years, since planet formation.¬† Long before humans arrived;  and yep, the ice caps melt, ocean levels change and humanity gets huge disruptions, then everything freezes up and people must move south to survive.



And, finally any huge heroic effort by humanity to change things one way or another would take another 100k years (one cycle) to measure the effect. 

I'll wait a few days and see which if any of my comments survive whoever has time and access to edit or eliminate my input.

It's pretty easy to get the impression that the narrative is being used as a political tool to try and get vast groups of people behind yet another 'crisis', then steer them to support a politician who puts himself up as a though-leader on the subject.  The game is to capture votes.

text: We're in an interglacial period of the ice age, which means that average worldwide temperatures should start to decrease (over the next few dozen millennia).  Fluctuations in average temperatures are normal, but not at the pace we're seeing now; the rapid increase in temperature is mostly, though not entirely, driven by greenhouse gas emissions.  It can be difficult to grasp for those of us who haven't dedicated our careers to climatology and other climate sciences, but the cause for concern is due to the rate at which it's changing.  100 years is a long time for us, but those of us who study the natural sciences know that a century is essentially nothing in geologic terms.  In the last century, average temperatures have increased a little less than 1¬∞C, which is the same change that is normally experienced in no less than 50,000 years.

text:
Ice ages are indeed controlled by orbital cycles.
But the true terrestrial feedback mechanism is ice sheet albedo (and dust), not CO2.
It is the sudden dust-peaks that lower ice-sheet albedo, and allow melting.
And the sudden dust peaks are caused by LOW CO2, not high CO2.
See my science paper on this.
Modulation of Ice Ages by Dust and Albedo
   https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674987116300305

Will we get a new ice age? The next Great Winter (Milankovitch Minima) is weak, so that is uncertain.
What we DO know is that CO2 has NO effect on ice ages.  When CO2 levels are high, the world cools i to an ice age.  When CO2 levels are low, the world warms into an interglacial.  The climate would not do that, if CO2 was the primary feedback system.  In truth, the primary feedback is ice albedo and dust.

So the primary thing that will prevent a new ice age is Chinese industrial dust on the northern ice sheets.  

And why is this guy afraid of high CO2 and warmth?  Dinosaurs thrived in that environment.  CO2 is plant food, and the most important gas in the atmosphere.  It is the increased plant growth, due to high CO2, that underpinned the large size of dinosaurs.  Conversely, it was the very low CO2 during the ice age maximum that created CO2 deserts and nearly kiIIed off all life on Earth.  

Ralph.
author: Ralph Ellis

"Around 10,800 BCE, likely within the span of 21 years between 10,818 BCE and 10,797 BCE, ‚àº9% of Earth's terrestrial biomass, on ‚àº10 million km2 (area as big as the US), burned.

The concentrations of soot, used to estimate the global amount of biomass burned, suggest that wildfires around 10,800 BCE consumed considerably more biomass than during the K-Pg extinction event.

It would be interesting to calculate how much CO2 must have been released when ‚àº9% of world terrestrial biomass on ‚àº10 million km2 burned.

It are the oceans and its currents that dictate the climate. Only the Sun can warm the ocean surface. CO2 back-radiation does not have the correct wavelength to penetrate the ocean deeper than its skin and therefore cannot heat the ocean. 
So we would need less clouds or a stronger Sun or less UV absorption in the atmosphere.
Even so if the poles get colder because of a circulation breakdown we immediately would see more ice created so saltier denser water and less melt water the exact conditions for restoring the system.
Also around the equator warmer seas would have more evaporation and therefore more cloud cover cooling the ocean.

text:
¬†@Ducthman¬† I think you‚Äôre forgetting the affects anoxia and acidification at the surface on everything that lives below that. With higher CO2 in the atmosphere, the ocean becomes more acidic, and with higher temperatures less oxygen rich. More CO2 can be held in water than is needed to become toxic to living things, let alone too acidic for exoskeletons of zooplankton to be built, so we don‚Äôt need to bother with CO2‚Äôs saturation since everything would be long asphyxiated before then. I should also say that the surface is where the depths get all their oxygen from. The depths will be slowly but surely asphyxiated.

Nutrient flow would also be impacted. Without the waterfall system, the deep sea weakens in its ability to support life due to low trace minerals. This mixing helps drive oceanic life beyond thermal vents at the sea floor. The twilight zone becomes much more isolated from the surface zone since the warm surface water mixes less with the cooler deep water, with species that require journeying between the depths and surface for food by night getting whittled down in numbers due to less food, temperature shock, anoxia, and acidification. Eventually, marine snow volumes decrease, making the midnight and abyssal depth detrivores (those who eat dead animal and plant matter) eventually begin to starve too, causing their predators to also starve. Without the stable surface, the oceans cease to be the bustling place of life we know them to be.

The poles‚Äô cooling and subsequent cooling over northern Europe doesn‚Äôt do enough to fully stop the greenhouse effect either. If anything, the effects wouldn‚Äôt have time to take hold as the climate keeps warming in a feedback loop from already existent ice loss. At most, the ice we have might be holding on for dear life for an additional few years before greenhouse gases caught up again. It couldn‚Äôt do much for long enough or fast enough to not still see widespread damage from warmer winters, since it takes centuries or millennia to grow enough permanent ice to combat our current level of warming.

Despite the ice holding on for just a little longer, we still have a much hotter equator anyway, levelling out the would be ‚Äúbenefits‚Äù of the cooler north even further. The temperate subtropics might have a lovely stable climate for a short while, less perturbed by seasonal variances (which many species rely on), but would see worse offshoots of freak weather from all that ocean evaporation in the tropics and drier cool air in the north and south. The evaporation wouldn‚Äôt do enough for cloud coverage, either. Clouds only last so long, only do so much for our albedo, and storms tend to wreck natural sources of greenhouse gas absorption anyway. The one positive thing from all the clouds would be the subsequent storms‚Äô lightning making a tiny amount of extra ozone, as we‚Äôd really want it with all the heating going on.

text: ¬†@Ducthman¬† Depends on what you're looking at. They're bad for the status quo. We have grown accustomed to our current climate and over a billion people live on the coast. Rising and falling sea levels have been normal for our ancestors. during the last Ice Age the sea levels were ca. 170m lower. Now that we depend on agriculture, need specific places to live in and have massive population sizes, only a slight increase in sea levels can be catastrophic. The holocene has been remarkably stable in climate, probably human small scale climate change played a role in that (CO2/Methane release through deforestation, rice and cattle agriculture etc.). Climate Change will mess with availability of space and feasability of agriculture (by influencing Jet Streams) it's not a problem for nature, but for humans. Currently we're releasing more CO2, CH4 and N2O than we can presumably adapt to in such a short time.
author: Hro√∞gar Fyrninga

text: ¬†@Ducthman¬† The increase in temperature causes the jet stream to stretch further north and south which makes certain weather constellations more long term, leading to longer periods drought or rainfall. Something that has been easy to observe this year. This is a major problem for agriculture, which will make it harder to sustain such a large population. We didn't have warm periods in the holocene that were as warm as they are/will be in future, so that doesn't say very much. Civilisation needs just the right balance.

text:
¬†@Hro√∞gar Fyrninga¬† 
If you say so. My information is that it is the other way around. As far as I know the Holocene has had warmer periods than today when trees could grow much higher up the mountain and much closer to the poles as they can on this moment.
You just wonder how dinosaurs could have thrived in a much warmer world for millions of years when a warmer world brings such unstable conditions.
author: Ducthman

text:
¬†@Ducthman¬† Yes, things were cooler than the holocene average 150 years ago, but they are warmer now. The warming also lags far behind the emissions, so even if we stopped emitting greenhousegasses right now, we'd reach around 1.5-2¬∞C warming above the holocene average, which is massive. 

There are a lot of factors to take into consideration when talking about the mesozoic. For example, the sun was less strong back then and landmasses were in different locations, leading to different climate and weather patterns. Early Dinosaurs were also adapted to the harsh conditions after the Permian mass extinction event (rise in global temperature by ca. 10¬∞C). Due to higher temperatures (especially during the Jurassic, if I remember correctly), there were also several anoxic events in the oceans, causing mass extinctions - the reason we have large oil reserves.

Second reason: do you know about continental drift? Well the Sahara region of Africa is moving Northward, which means that where the Sahara used to be more south, at the equator where the climate is wetter because of the zenith of the sun (I learned this in my climatology classes when completing my degree), it rains along the equator as air rises the most there and loses its humidity, but when is comes back down to earth north and south of the equator, the air is already bone dry and so regions just North and South of the equator are arid, where lies the Sahara desert today, as all the deserts are located in the tropic regions of the earth.

text:
The entire existence of the Gulf Stream is contingent on the saltier waters not significantly mixing with the surrounding waters, due to differences in density. Otherwise, the salinity and temperature of all ocean waters would simply equalize, and the whole thing wouldn't work. So how is it that under current conditions mixing does not take place, but under conditions of melting polar ice, with a far greater salinity, and therefore density, gradient, this principle would suddenly reverse itself and the waters would mix freely, decreasing the salinity of Gulf Stream waters north of Iceland?
I'm not trying to pee in the corn flakes, but predictive models that depend on changing physical laws are always suspect. There is good theoretical reason to suspect the NASA data is correct.

text: No. The 100,000,000 km**3 / second that supposedly "sinks" at 5:04 is grossly exaggerated. The correct amount is 17,500,000 km**3 / second (so 17.5%). The other 82.5% is an entirely-unrelated thing which is the wind-driven North Atlantic Ocean clockwise gyre which doesn't sink but simply gets spun clockwise at the surface. This, obviously, is unaffected by the thermohaline circulation (THC) and that's why the "Could Global Warming Start A New Ice Age?" in title is just a pile of silly bull shit at the Europeans, and exaggeration of 6x the actual effect. Also, at 9:58 "when average global temperatures decreased by about 1 degree Celsius. Bull shit. This idiot has the chutzpah to then show the global temperature proxies at 10:22 and you see that average global temperatures didn't decrease by about 1 degree Celsius. From Medieval Warm Period (MWP) peak to stupidly-named Little Ice Age lowest is clearly seen on that plot to be an average global temperatures decrease of 0.42 +/- 0.27 degrees, not "about 1 degree". With stupid, lazy, inaccurate rubbish like this the video presenter is actively assisting the coal/oil shills & coal/oil shill-fuckwits with their "natural cycle" drivel. Rubbishy, error packed, inaccurate science in this video.

text:
¬†@A potato¬†   Wow that is cold.  Yeah that‚Äôs pretty darn cold if even C and F sync up.  We have some extremely cold places here in the US too.  Where I live though it‚Äôs an average of 30 F in the winter with nightly lows in the 10s F.  Last year was one of the 8th warmest winters on record where I live with an average of 4 degrees higher than normal.  

So, I do live in what people here consider a cold state, but it‚Äôs still not like that.  Though we have had severely cold winters before.  Our coldest temperature on record was -39 F in 1899.  

It is difficult from my perspective to see an ice age occurring when here literally for the past 10 years it‚Äôs been the warmest winters on record here.  But, I don‚Äôt necessarily count out the possibility.

text: In the 1970s and to the mid 1980s, the scare tactic was the impending ice age.  It was in all the media.  Classes were interrupted so, "Environmental awareness experts," could preach their doom.  Well, it started warming up when sun spot activity started slowing down so there was a purging period in the late 1980s to mid 1990.  Very little, if anything, was said about the impending ice age so people would forget the old scare tactics.  The. The late 1990s brought forth the new scare tactic, "global warming." Most people had forgetten about the impending ice age scare that were still alive. I did not forget because I had a teacher terrify me about it.  It put a mental scar of fear that will never heal.  A teacher cried in front of class while reading out of a, "Scientific American," that was spreading doom about how the northern hemisphere was going to be under two and a half miles of ice by 2010.  I actually believed it.  I guess I am grateful. The teacher reading the doom frieghtened me enough that I remembered those days.

It‚Äôs called the doldrums and the air doesn‚Äôt blow nor does the water move but a drift. 3) That thermohaline doesn‚Äôt make any sense either, because if the coldest and saltiest water is the heaviest how can warmer and fresher water sink past colder and saltier water?  How does the colder and saltier water rise if it‚Äôs continually heavier. 4) The latitude argument is atrocious. There‚Äôs only one place you‚Äôll find consistent weather, the latitudes of the equator. Get off the Man Made Climate Change fallacy. text: ¬†@Sir. SuperThunderGoodGuy lll¬† Thats two separate questions that you connected. Is it warmer now than 120 years ago? - and Are we causing it? The first answer is yes and is easy to prove. But if you ask the same question with a different point in time, the answer will be different. Is it warmer than 90 years ago? Definitely no and it is just as easy to prove. In the 1930s there were heat waves in the northern hemisphere that were much more severe than today. Your second question, are we causing it  - requires that we agree on the first question. If you compare 1970-1980 to 1950-1960  then it is verifyably false. There is a famous song by Rudi Carell in which he laments that the summers of the 70s are so cold. And he braggs about the summers of his childhood in the 50s which were warm and sunny all through the summer. Please check this yourself if you are a critical thinker.  I hope you understand that a question like the one you posed is not as easy to answer. Also please check, if you can, that the warming from 1990-2000 is over now. Right now we are in a proces of steady cooling. The freezing temperatures in May are an indication but not a solid proof for that. But the cooling of the atlantic ocean is a verifyable process. You can observe this yourself if you accept that the reduced rain and the drying of the country in europe is due to less ocean water evaporation. I guess you will immediately agree that the last 3 summers are dryer than before but you draw the false conclusion. A warm ocean evaporates more water and brings more rain - not a cold ocean! So if you put aside all your prejudices and use meterological knowledge, you will understand climate a little better and maybe you also recognize that much of what they tell you is sheer nonsense.

text: ¬†@Dundoril¬† The only interesting comment was your link to GISS data, so I am confronting you with NOAA data, the link works but you have to be patient, it sometimes takes up to a minute. You will find that the present global average temperature is   13.97¬∞C, which is even below 14¬∞C.  Exchanging references is like playing a card game. After playing this for a week, you may realize that these questions cannot be satisfactorily decided by just citing public data. You need something more, like e.g. knowledge about the climate phases through the last holocene. This helps to check statements made in these publications, on correctness. Also detected contradictions tell you that something is wrong. Your GISS curve has a number of weaknesses. First, it starts with end of the little ice age (LIA), as do many sources that want to misslead. Of course, after the LIA, all temperatures are warmer, but do you know how warm it was before the LIA? Probably not! Then it shows no absolute temperatures - only anomalies. The second problem is the 1930s. The GISS curve is flat here, but this is a period, where newspapers already existed. An these newspapers from USA, to Europe and to Australia tell you that it was the hottest phase in the 20th century. Strange, GISS has flattened that. Why? Then we had a warming pause after the year 2000. Many independent institutions confirmed that. There were even articles on "the pause", asking, did the warming stop or is this just a temporary phenomenon. You GISS curve is in stark contradiction to previous publications, even by the IPCC. This is an embarrassing work by indecent people.

text:
Ice ages and interglacial eras have nothing to do with CO2 concentrations. Remember, when CO2 is high during an interglacial the world cools, and when CO2 is low at the glacial maximum, the world warms. Yes - counterintuitive, isn‚Äôt it... 



So what controls and modulates the interglacial cycle? Answer - orbital cycles and ice sheet albedo. 

Milankovitch orbital cycles provide the basis, but the surface feedback mechanism is albedo, not CO2. The albedo effect as measured in the high NH latitudes is orders of magnitude greater that any CO2 effects. Ice ages would continue indefinitely, if the high albedo of the ice-sheets could not be lowered. 



So what lowers ice sheet albedo? Answer - dust. 

 It is a fact that sudden dust-storms lasting for millennia, lower the ice sheet albedo just before every interglacial. Why these dust-storms suddenly happen, is fully explained in the science paper: Ice Age Modulation by Dust and Albedo. This dust production process is caused by CO2, but not in the manner you might imagine. 



See these Ice age modulation videos, based upon the science paper: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=99EHhiKG1ZI 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Fm2KMMrtXI R

The reason NY is colder than Europe at the same latitude has nothing to do with Gulf Stream but with the fact that in the northern hemisphere, the wind blows from West to East and NY is at the Eastern part of the USA which means in winter the air blows from Western USA to Eastern USA and as it does, it cools off and reaches NY much colder than on the Western side of the USA, where temperatures are similar to Western Europe.
Why do you think the coldest winter temperatures are in Eastern Siberia? Its again because the whole Asian continent cools off in winter and the air goes from West to East and when it reaches Eastern Siberia is at its coldest.
Similarly in summer, because the USA warms up, the East part of the USA is warmer than the Western USA.
There is a warm current similar to Gulfstream called Kuroshio on the coast of china and Japan that should make China and Japan mild and they are not. They are as cold as Eastern USA in winter which proves that ocean warm currents have absolutely no impact on the costal temperature.
Gulf Stream does absolutely nothing!  Its a myth !!

text:
We're currently in the middle of an Ice Age. The Earth has experienced five major ice ages and this one is called the Quaternary. It has been characterized by alternating periods of glaciation averaging 70,000-90,000 years and interglacial warming periods of 10,000-30,000 years.
There have been approximately a dozen epochs of glaciation interspersed with interglacials over the last million years. Our current interglacial, the Holocene epoch, began about 12,000 years ago. At the peak of the last glaciation, about 18,000 years ago, there were ice caps and glaciers over two miles high covering Detroit and much of North America, Europe, and the southern parts of South America and Africa.

text:
Dusty Boot 
Just because CO2 was high doesn‚Äôt always be temperatures will too. 
https://www.skepticalscience.com/co2-higher-in-past.htm

‚ÄúRecent research has uncovered evidence for lower ocean temperatures during the Ordovician than previously thought, creating ideal conditions for a huge spurt in marine  biodiversity and correspondingly large drawdown of CO2 from the atmosphere through carbon burial in the ocean. A  period of mountain-building was also underway (the so-called Taconic orogeny) increasing the amount of rock weathering taking place and subsequently lowering CO2 levels even further. The evidence is definitely there for a short-term disruption of the carbon cycle.

Another important factor is the sun. During the Ordovician, it would have been several percent dimmer according to established nuclear models of main sequence stars. Surprisingly, this raises the CO2 threshold for glaciation to a staggering 3000 ppmv or so. This also explains (along with the logarithmic forcing effect of CO2) why a runaway greenhouse didn't occur: with a dimmer sun, high CO2 is necessary to stop the Earth freezing over.

In summary, we know CO2 was probably very high coming into the Late Ordovician period, however the subsequent dip in CO2 was brief enough not to register in the GEOCARB model, yet low enough (with the help of a dimmer sun) to trigger permanent ice-formation. Effectively it was a brief excursion to coldness during an otherwise warm era, due to a coincidence of conditions.‚Äù

CO2 levels dropped but very briefly. That plus a dimmer sun and Earth had ice. The issue is you guys are confusing a glaciation with a snow ball. It wasn‚Äôt a large ice age. It was some brief cooling and some brief ice sheets in a very warm period in Earths history. 

We know the current warming caused by humans is definitely CO2. Us pumping tons of it into the air is acting as a greenhouse causing Earth to warm. 
https://www.google.com/amp/s/climate.nasa.gov/evidence.amp 

You can‚Äôt just say myths to fit your, well, whatever thing your trying to prove. That fact is CO2 is a greenhouse gas. The more you put in the air the warmer Earth‚Äôs temperature gets. 

Current CO2 is at 415 ppmv. The highest 5 million years and the last time CO2 was that high, temperatures globally were 3¬∞C warmer than today. There was no ice on Greenland then but there was ice on Antarctica. CO2 levels could be as high as 1,000 ppmv by 2100. That last time CO2 was that high was during the Palogene over 50 million years ago. During this time Earth warmed 5-8¬∞C in 20,000 years and the peak Hearing during this time was almost 10¬∞C hotter than today. Earth was ice free. The reason for this warm period was all because of CO2. The main cause is unknown but CO2 did warm the planet than. And the greenhouse effect is occurring. If we were to remove all the CO2 out of the air alone, Earth would be way to cold for life. But if we had too much CO2. Things will get way to Hot.
