text:
Dusty Boot CO2 dose cause global warming. 
https://climatefeedback.org/claimreview/simple-measurements-demonstrate-that-co2-is-a-greenhouse-gas-tim-ball/

As for the sun. No, it‚Äôs been dimming the last couple decades yet Earth keeps on getting warmer.
https://climate.nasa.gov/faq/14/is-the-sun-causing-global-warming/ 

Even if the sun was getting brighter (which it‚Äôs not) it operates on such long time scales that it‚Äôs not enough to cause earth to warm. 

‚ÄúOne of the ‚Äúsmoking guns‚Äù that tells us the Sun is not causing global warming comes from looking at the amount of the Sun‚Äôs energy that hits the top of the atmosphere. Since 1978, scientists have been tracking this using sensors on satellites and what they tell us is that there has been no upward trend in the amount of the Sun‚Äôs energy reaching Earth.‚Äù

‚ÄúA second smoking gun is that if the Sun were responsible for global warming, we would expect to see warming throughout all layers of the atmosphere, from the surface all the way up to the upper atmosphere (stratosphere). But what we actually see is warming at the surface and cooling in the stratosphere. This is consistent with the warming being caused by a build-up of heat-trapping gases near the surface of the Earth, and not by the Sun getting ‚Äúhotter.‚Äù

text:
Almost everything in this is, 'would be' or 'could be'. None of the predictions have happened, only signs that they could.

Most of the drought affected areas have got to that stage by human intervention, not by Anthropogenic Climate Change.
 If there has been any effect from higher global temperature and/or high CO2, it is that we are growing more than ever before in history. Images from NASA show the main deserts of the world are greening.

 Weigh that up against what happened 700 years ago when global temperature dropped by 1 degree C, I know what I prefer; Warm, not cold.

Between 1300 and 1850, global temperatures dropped and rose but generally dropped 1 degree C, causing crop failures, disease and wars, which in turn caused the deaths of over 70 million people out of a population close to 1 billion.
 Canals and rivers in Great Britain and the Netherlands were frequently frozen deeply enough to support ice skating and winter festivals, like never before. This is evidenced by painters showing these episodes happening in their paintings that exist today.

 The world recovered that 1 degree and added another degree and the result of that was, more growth than ever before and a rise in population to 8 billion.

 Scientists agree on one thing, they really don't know how to explain fully what has happened or what has caused the large variations of climate and they only have speculation on the furure.
The one thing that IS certain,
using models on climate is a waste of time.
None so far have come true.

text:
You forget to take into account that you're looking at the East Coast of America. If you compare the West Coast, we see similar temperatures up to Portland and Vancouver than in Europe. Although, sure, it is on a much thinner strip. But at 3:40 you clearly show a circulation map with a cold current around the East Coast of America and a warm one on the West Coast, similar to the warm current in Europe.
Add to that the fact that Europe has 2 and a half inland seas (the Mediterranean, the Baltic and the North Sea that, although connected to the Arctic, is still continental crust meaning shallow waters ‚Äî¬†also keep in mind that's the case for the English Channel and the Irish Sea), then the warmer temperatures and, most importantly, warmer winters make sense. Water acts as a buffer since it takes much longer to cool down than land. That's why part of Russia that are at the same latitude as the UK are much much colder. Scotland, for example, is further North than Moscow. It's a lot warmer, though. Same goes for Norway. If you stick to the US, San Francisco and Sacramento are basically at the same latitude as Washington DC.


Now, would ice melting completely nullify those currents? Well, sure, there have been examples of the Gulf Stream halting to a stop and all. But salinity is not the only thing driving these currents. It's also trade winds that are linked to the Coriolis effect. And whatever you do, water to the south will be warmer, pushing it to the surface and making it expand, while colder water will sink.


But sure, climate is complex and it will be a whole mess.




As for a word that means "less salty"? Fresher. Fresher water. Since it's called fresh water.

Remember the importance of language !! Potential, Theory, possibility, ext. As humans we only live in average 70 years, in the scheme of the planet's climate history, our existence doesn't even register. The planet has been worming since the last ice age. Sea levels have risen over 400 feet and counting, we are so arrogant to think, we have the capability to influence the climate. Yes we're polluting rivers and putting plastics in the oceans where they don't belong. But when it comes to changing the climate, the sun is king !! There are billions of tons of CO2 being released through vents on the oceans floors throughout the planet. We humans haven't got a clue about the effects that it may have.

text:
We didn't cause warming. We didn't cause acceleration of that warming either. 

But we are accelerating that acceleration.

That means, if humans stop doing human activity thingies, the Earth will still be warming...at an accelerated rate.

Even if you took a time machine to before the industrial revolution and erased all humans, the Earth would still be warming...and that warming would be accelerating.

In the video, the narrator talks about stopping this, which is disingenuous.

We can't stop warming. Nor can we stop the acceleration of that warming.
.
All we can do is stop adding our bit of acceleration.

author: R. R.

text:
¬†@R. R.¬† The warming itself is not a problem. It's the rate of change of several factors that's the problem.

There are many factors that can reverse that warming (for a relatively short time). Each one is a the potential straw that breaks the camels back. Not just CO2.

Normally, other factors have enough time to balance the scales.

E.g., in previous ice ages CO2 was much higher. But irradiance from the Sun was lower than today. Which created a balance. Fast changes in either threw things off balance. (This is true for a myriad of other things too)

It's the rate of change that's disconcerting.

Human activity is definitely pushing that balance.

But nature has been doing the same for the last 11700 years. We live at a time during a 405 thousand year cycle when the Earth's orbit is most circular (this is apart from the 100 year Milankovitch cycle...which has also aligned to cause more warming)

On top of that. The Sun also has cycles of irradiance. And it too is irradiating more since it's minimum during the mini-Ice Age...and will do so for the next 2000+ years. (I.e. The Sun is gonna be hotter)

So human activity is just one factor. A significant factor yes. But removing the human factor won't remove what's coming. 

A whole lot more warming.

text: Global warming activists have created a false narrative in their attempt to frighten humans to stop polluting the planet, which is a very necessary goal with or without the added component of the effect on climate change. Every school child (should know) knows that 70k to 20k years ago much of Europe and North America was covered by glaciers. The remnants of these glaciers are still visible as they steadily recede alias melt. What made the glaciers start melting 20k years ago? Global warming. When did the industrial age begin? Roughly two hundred years ago. That leaves 18k years of melting without humans polluting the atmosphere to any significant degree. The problem with environmental activists tying everything to global warming is that the truth is there's no way to stop global warming or even slow it down and the minute this concept is discredited the need for reducing atmospheric pollution also will be discredited by people who want cheap energy, fertilizer and plastic products from fossil fuels. Unfortunately there are still a lot of us who were taught that the frightening part of polluting the atmosphere wasn't the warming part but the tipping point when a new ice age would begin. Moving coastal population back from the sea over 50 - 200 years is totally doable but surviving sudden glaciation of much of the temperate zones where the bulk of the world's food is produced will mean the end of Civilization.

text:
sean hurley 
Here‚Äôs how the last ice age ended. I hoped you guys could have figured it out. 
So during an ice age Earth goes through orbital cycles known as Milankovitch cycles. This changes that amount of solar output hitting the earths surface. This warms the planet releasing CO2 and other greenhouse gasses this warming the planet. This happens through climate feedback loops and earth enters an warm interglacial period. These changes are slow, taking about 10,000 years the planet warms about 5¬∞C during this time. Which is pretty fact on geologic timescale though not nearly as fast as the current warming. Than once in your in an interglacial, earths climate is stable. 

I‚Äôll pop a link to how Milankovitch cycles work and their effect on Earths climate system. 
https://climate.nasa.gov/news/2948/milankovitch-orbital-cycles-and-their-role-in-earths-climate/
author: Sir. SuperThunderGoodGuy lll

text:
¬†@Sir. SuperThunderGoodGuy lll¬† ¬†¬† Don't need the link bud. That is exactly my understanding too. I left a question for you at the bottom. Just wondering what your dispute was with Pak De was. I don't think he denied human involvment. I think he was suggesting that we can do little (he said "nothing") to stop global warming in comparison to planet earth's natural cycles.

You mentioned the SUN warmed the planet via Milankovitch cycle, releasing CO2, which then of course would have warmed it more. The sun warming the planet also would have melted ice, warming it more.

So if global warming, CO2, and melting ice were all happening at once (as the glacial period ended)... WHY would it suddenly stop and become stable? Why not a runaway effect?
author: sean hurley

text: sean hurley because Earths temperatures stabilizes at called Earth‚Äôs equilibrium. However the more greenhouse gasses you add in the air the warmer the equilibrium is. Another reason why earth dose not rapidly warm is because the forcing causing earth to warm in the first place stops. Nothing lasts forever.

Milankovitch cycles were changing causing earth to be cooling about 0.5¬∞C the last 6,000 years but humans have reversed all of that. Now we‚Äôre in a rapid warming. text:
sean hurley I explained why it stoped. The forcing causing Earth to warm stoped. That was changed in Milankovitch cycles. CO2 and temperatures stabilized and global temperatures were very stable throughout the Holocene with some very slight regional warming and coolings through out the epoch. 

As for I want an ice age. Um no, I don‚Äôt. The reason why I think we should stop human caused global warming is that humans can not survive a world that‚Äôs 4¬∞C to 5¬∞C hotter than today. Not been seen for tens of millions of years. A hot house won‚Äôt be good for humanity. But an ice age won‚Äôt be good either. The current interglacial is fine. The Holocene is the reason why humans arose. So anything much warmer or colder would be bad. Now are their positives to global warming? Yes, some, but are out weighed by the negatives. And the cooling we were seeing before Anthropoecene warming, we were not going to see another glacial period for another 20,000 years. And human caused global warming has already delayed the next ice age by 100,000+ years or even permanently. Some scientists think we may have even ended the Quanterney period all together. 

I‚Äôm not saying the worlds going to end as many alarmist claim. But we shouldn‚Äôt ignore the threat of climate change that many ‚Äúskeptics‚Äù deny. I think it‚Äôs best we use renewable energys and let nature do its work. And I‚Äôm not concerned about an ice age in 20,000 years, because by then we should definitely be exploring space. But that‚Äôs less of concern than a hot house potentially in a century or two. 

I like warm weather, I like the heat, but what we have now is fine. :)

text:
New, satellite probing has discovered a vast, lake bed under the sands of the Sahara, as big as the Great Lakes combined, along with river and stream beds radiating north and south. MUCH warmer than today, of course, and the water dried up and sand filled in the depressions. This means that the event was relatively fast, geologically speaking. 


This would also mean that the Mediterranean may have been much warmer along with most of Europe. In the British Isles, they have found coconut shells dating back only a few thousand years. In the far North of Europe we have flash frozen Woolly Mammoth and Mastodons, many with undigested food in their stomach. Now THAT'S flash frozen. 


Thing is, things didn't happen over millions of years, they happened catastrophically. A new theory of geology called catastrophism. Take mountains with their sharp peaks. If they took million of years to form, erosion would have rounded those peaks, even as they formed.

text: ¬†@Leshrac¬† Climate change is natural forcing plus human forcing. The current models used to push AGW do not include all sources of natural climate forcing. The biggest factor left out is cloud formation resulting from cosmic rays and solar particles. Therefore, if the models do not take in to account all sources of natural climate forcing, one cannot honestly say that man is the cause og global warming. CIMP6 includes some solar forcing but not enough. There is loads of research in some of the biggest pier reviewed journals on the topic of solar and cosmic climate forcing.
author: Chris Parker

text: ¬†@Sir. SuperThunderGoodGuy lll¬† All I have to do to refute your comments is show the impact of solar and cosmic forces on our climate. Your argument relies on the notion that solar and cosmic forces have little to no impact on earth's climate. As I previously stated, climate change = human forcing + natural forcing. Let's say A is natural forcing, B is human forcing, C is total climate change. So, A + B = C. If I show that solar and cosmic forces have a significant impact on earth's climate, the entire equation is changed. It will also show that, no, the models DO NOT include all natural variabilities and that human forcing is certainly not the cause of 100% of the global warming. Hopefully we can agree on this basic logic. With that said, I will have an long list of research showing a significant influence of solar and cosmic forcing posted in a few.

author: Kent Vigilante

text:
He did however say there was no consensus. And he later forgot to include a crucial aspect from early on: "the westerlies" pushing warm water towards Europe. As long as the AMOC stays intact, it will keep Europe warmer. 


Second,  he makes no mention of solar activity. The Maunder Minimum etc. are closely related to solar activity cycles, specifically the 115 year cycle. Right now we're at a minimum, yet still temperatures rise globally and now even in the Antarctic ice cap shrinks. In about 60 years there's the solar maximum. This further speeds up ice melt, and I don't think there is any telling of what effect this will have at the deep ocean current. The massive cold "unsalty" water dump can drastically slow down the deep current, but if in 60 - 70 years there isn't much Arctic ice left to melt anymore... that dump is over really fast.


Third, the more Arctic ice retreats, the more the cool surrounding meltwater retraits too, that creates a northern barrier for both the westerlies and AMOC.

Fourth, the past years we've seen cold air being pushed down from the Arctic, particularly in N-America. With ever more ice melting, this push weakens. Meaning warmer air farther up north. Which then ties into the end of my second point.

But at this point much is still speculation. Whatever influence becomes dominant, it's going to get real unpleasant near the equator.

text:
@¬†@Magn√∫s √ñrn¬† First of all the use of the word "deniers" in the headline gives this away as a smear piece, which is what passes for science in the fraudulent field of "climatology". 

But more importantly, the IPCC lied in 2011 before the Copenhagen meeting. Why would they need to lie if this had any relation to reality? They wouldn't, obviously. Yet they did. text:
All of that is true, but it does not link anything to co2.

Wildfires are worse in areas that the government has refused to allow procedures proven to limit¬† wildfires. Safe burns can clear out the Underbrush and firebreaks can slow the fires when they happen, but Australia has gone so far as to threaten farmers and others that want to maintain their own land. California is almost that bad.

Ice shelves are melting, but the interior ice is increasing in both Greenland and Antarctica. The balance is towards more ice, not less.

How long are the records for snow patterns? Temperature? Few places in the world have consistent records going back more than a few decades.

Are you even aware that the earliest thermometers were invented in the little ice age. That means that the earliest we could have any real records was when the earth was in the deep freeze. IF you use proxies from beginning to end, nothing has changed much¬†except we are slightly cooler than the mwp.

Yes we are warming, but the reality is we are recovering from the little ice age. It is not co2.

author: Alice

text:
Notice you said "in just 30 years".

There is a 60 year cycle that happens if the earth is warming or cooling and has done so for thousands of years, that we can find its imprint. When the earth is in a cooling trend, such as in the early days of the little ice age, the 30 years of the warming half cancels a portion of the cooling. Then the 30 years of the cooling half increases it.

When the earth is in a warming trend, such as since the end of the last phase of the little ice age, in the early 1800's, the trend can be even be¬†reverse temporarily, such as in the 1960's, when the temperature fell slightly. From 1970's to 2000 we were in a warming trend AND a warming half of the cycle, so it warmed rapidly. Since then there has been a period when only the other cycles are doing anything. Two El Nino's (still no one knows what causes them or if there is any cycle to them) and the hot side of a 12 year cycle made the last half of the 2010's look hot.

It is a fact that in a control environment, co2 WILL cause an increase, but the truth is not that simple. The earth is not an enclosed environment. Study have proven that the atmospheric¬†sensitivity to an increase in co2 is less than .5¬∞C per doubling. That means that if co2 increases from 400 ppm to 800 ppm by 2100, the total increased caused by co2 AND all feedbacks¬†would be .5¬∞.

Unless there is an increase of 3¬∞c there is no way they can predict a disaster.

text:
It's "The Day After Tomorrow"s plot, rehashed. Back in 2004, Roland Emmerich (the director famous for "Independence Day,") made a Climate-Change fueled sci-fi movie about Global Warming reaching such a hostile pinnacle that the "Gulf Stream," or "North Atlantic Current," lost all salinity due to rampant melting polar ice, and completely shut down. What makes this film fictional is the idea that the current shutting down caused an immediate planetary climate-holocaust that affected the entire Northern Hemisphere, and a month-long, planet-wide blizzard that covered everything down to Mexico and Africa in hundreds of feet of snow. 


Now, obviously, the speed at which this event happened was entirely fictional. No Ice Age ever came about in a matter of weeks or months. It came about in YEARS, if not centuries. But the fundamental theory that shapes the film, according to this video, is absolutely plausible! If the North Atlantic Current (which powers the entire world's current-system by sheer momentum) were to break down. The ocean's natural recycling of warm water to northern climates would cease. Over time, this would cause an equalization of Earth's latitudinal temperature rules, causing hightened warming at the equator, but excessive cooling at the polar ice caps. The ice caps themselves would, over centuries, replenish their ice sheets and traditional cycles, but at the expense of the warm-temperate climate, worldwide, that enabled mankind to dominate the Earth to begin with. 


As this video points out; it would happen VERY SLOWLY, (over a century's length, at the very fastest) so none of us alive now would ever live to see the final result. It might even be happening right at this moment, but since we're at the very beginning of this process, none of us can notice. To us, the Earth seems to be still warming. It'll take years, if not decades, for that momentum we are all used to seeing, to slow to a stop. Decades beyond that to move in the opposite direction. Nothing by Earth's standards moves fast. If an Ice Age of our own cause is approaching, it is not us, but our children, and most prominently our grandchildren, who will face the consequences. "The Day After Tomorrow" appears to be a not only plausible, but LIKELY, outcome of our fiddling with nature. It just won't happen at "Hollywood Speed." It'll happen at (pardon the expression) a "glacial" pace. We'll live long enough to see the beginning of the process, but none of us will ever live long enough to see the end result of it. 


And none of us may want to. Enjoy your paradise while it lasts...

text:
Good production value, but wrong on climate. CO2 does not drive temperature. Just look at any time scale graph comparing temperature and CO2. All but one have virtually zero correlation, suggesting that any correlation is merely accidental and not cause-and-effect. On the one time scale with a strong correlation (10s to 100s of thousands of years; Al Gore's favorite), scientists found that it's temperature that does the driving -- driving CO2 into and out of the oceans as a dissolved gas (soda fizz, anyone?).


In fact, climate sensitivity to CO2 is under 1¬∞C per doubling of CO2, because of the level of warming from the beginning of the Industrial Revolution to today. Climate changes in cycles and we were already scheduled for a major warm period (1,000-year cycle). Nature was set up to give us a major portion of warming and humans added CO2. The result was the coldest major warm period of the entire Holocene (excluding the Younger Dryas and earlier). We're still not up to Viking standards on Greenland climate, and the Medieval Warm Period, plus Little Ice Age were global phenomena according to these scientists:

Y. Rosenthal, B. Linsley, et al (2013)
M.A. Cioccale (1999)
D. Mauquoy, M. Blaauw, et al (2004)
T. Haberzettl, M. Fey, et al (2005)
T. Kellerhals, S. Brutsch, et al (2010)
M. Vuille, S.J. Burns, et al (2012)
B. Jenny, B.L. Valero-Garces, et al (2002)
P.L. Nester, E. Gayo, et al (2007)
L. Rebolledo, J. Sepulveda, et al (2008)
L. von Gunten, M. Grosjean, et al (2009)
J. Sepulveda, S. Pantoja, et al (2009)
M.-S. Fletcher and P.I. Moreno (2012)
P.J. Polissar, M.B. Abbott, et al (2006)
A.J. Chepstow-Lusty, K.D. Bennett, et al (1998)
B. Rein A. Luckge, and F. Sirocko (2004)
R. Bracco, L. del Puerto, et al (2011)
G.H. Haug, K.A. Hughen, et al (2001)
M.A. Goni, M.P. Woodworth, et al (2004)
R. Neukom, J. Luterbacher, et al (2011)

And, we already live in an Ice Age!!! And the Holocene is not the warmest interglacial of the Pleistocene, either. Not by a long shot.

text:
You do realise we're in an ice-age right now, don't you?  It's called the "Quaternary glaciation".  Google it.  In fact, we're in a relatively short, and unusually warm period WITHIN and ice age.  This warm period is called the Holocene (Once again, google it.) however obviously this short period or reprieve from the ice will end at some point, and the  Quaternary will resume it's normal colder weather.  


The 2050 solar minimum is rapidly approaching, which could very well trigger the end of the Holocene.  Research sun-cycles to learn more about the 2050 solar minimum.  (It's interesting stuff, related to sun-spots, which are caused by many of the planets in our solar system being on the same side of the sun, which stresses the sun and causes spots.)



So yeah - the upcoming "cold period" can be predicted and explained entirely by planetary movement.  There's no need to awkwardly try to link the human-caused CO2 "global warming" model into it.


I guess it's good that the climate-change-hystericals are updating their predictions, so they don't look like total idiots in 2050.  Now, according to the hystericals, CO2 causes global warming, which is going to cause global cooling.  <facepalm>  I guess cold is the new hot or something.


Sadly, the climate-change buttheads are STILL trying to "prevent global warming" like total morons, despite the fact that the impending threat is global cooling.  We're gonna have to burn a lot of trees in 2049, to get more CO2 in the air, and keep this planet warm.


The biggest question is, how did this video about ice-ages fail to mention that we're in a damn ice-age?  Who researched this?  A headless chicken?

text: It has nothing to do with man made anything. As humans we are responsible for as little as 4% of all the co2 emissions currently. Even if high co2 levels could cause a warming this would not be enough, because it is a non accumulative gas that begins breaking down and being absorbed by all the carbon based life on the planet, and to date there has been no actual science done to show if co2 even has the ability to cause a warming affect. NASA recently released data that shows the planet is getting greener ( more plant life), which would verify that the small amount of additional co2 we are responsible for is being absorbed as fast as we are making it. Also the ocean currents are controlled by orbital influences as are the winds and the jet streams and the rivers of lava beneath our feet. The process you described wouldn‚Äôt be enough our cause the ocean currents. And the reason the currents appear to stop during ice ages is because ice sheets don‚Äôt flow very well. Interesting the global warming crowd is now doubling down saying the current and future cooling we are heading towards is because of the global warming we didn‚Äôt believe them about. üòÇ A couple of years back NASA also released data showing the Antarctic ice shelf is about 20% more in volume since we‚Äôve been keeping track. These global warming guys didn‚Äôt skip a beat and began to blame it on global warming, and then really got themselves worked up about, wait if there‚Äôs more ice then why are the ocean levels rising, it was almost complete hysteria. The oceans haven‚Äôt risen, even if all the ice melted, the oceans don‚Äôt behave like your coffee cup or bath tube. Land sinks land heaves, increased evaporations so on. It‚Äôs just another stupid scare tactic like the ocean currents, we will be drowning but some how all dying of thirst in the same sentence nonsense. Natural systems doing there natural cycles. If anything we are doing a good thing by releasing all that locked up co2, so all the carbon based life forms can thrive.

text: Thank you for explaining the cyclic pattern of ice ages and the periods between them. People tend to think the logical conclusion of a run-a-way greenhouse effect is "fireball earth", which of course is silly. Global climate changes happen very slowly and then all at once. Those all at once periods are called tipping points. They happen with both warming and cooling periods. The earth is located in our solar system to not only be conducive to life but also one that creates a climatic spectrum of environmental factors to challenge living organisms to evolve. I know, change is hard. But we as humans can enjoy our ability to employ migratory patterns in response to our changing environment as we have always done in the past. The climate of the earth can not be viewed within the existence of human life on earth. To lends some perspective, the dinosaurs were on earth for millions of years, we have not been in existence for half a million years (plus lots of different life in between). The only constant in human life is the perception that the sky is always falling.

text: Oh, brother. "Climate change" has also caused both hotter and colder weather. We are in a solar minimum period which will continue into the next cycle++ and create even more cooling. If you want to understand climatic changes, you have to understand solar cycles and solar forcing in addition to ocean oscillation, the main climate drivers. CO2 is completely irrelevant. Atmospheric particle levels were MUCH higher during periods of high volcanic activity which caused much cooler weather. Ice cores show clearly that evergreen forests once thrived on the south pole while ice was completely absent from the north polar area.These are very normal cycles that ultimately sort themselves, obviously. More CO2 = more green plants and faster tree growth. At 400 ppm, CO2 is at deficit levels for optimal plant growth. Global warming is politics, not science. Yada yada yada ... and all of those past 'extreme' cycles happened well before industrialization and the use of fossil fuels. You need to figure out how to control the sun and stop H2O (the main greenhouse gas) evaporation, not people. Good luck with that!  At least the powers that be have figured out that the gig is just about up on the runaway warming propaganda. Now, they're coming up with non-sense for how (human-caused) warming equals increasing cooling. lol  At least they'll have less egg on their faces when the planet hasn't melted down in 12 years. Hmmm... but what to do about Greta Thunberg which she figures out she was duped and made a pawn for a political agenda to take away liberty from her generation. I hope Al Gore will at least offer to pay for her inevitable therapy sessions. Child abuse should be illegal ... for all.

I'd bet the people of Saharan Africa would find a silver lining to this story as increasing temperatures over Africa would cause a seasonal low pressure system that would draw in monsoon rains to the Sahara Desert, convering it to Savannah lands. So while Europe, India and North America would suffer, other places would experience an economic boom as formerly infertile lands would become the new breadbasket of the world.
Regardless of what we do or don't do, climate change is always occurring, so we have to be prepared to adapt our economy to the changing climates as they occur or suffer the consequences of complacency and inflexibility.

author: epicrotfl

text:
¬†@epicrotfl¬†... The Quartenary did not end 11000 years ago. It still continues.

What ended 11700 years ago was a glacial period (called the Pleistocene Epoch) within the current ice age (called the Quartenary Period) .

An Ice Age has glacial and interglacial periods.

Glacial periods are periods of glacial expansion (rapid global cooling)

Interglacial periods are periods of glacial retreat (rapid global warming.) We are currently in an interglacial, called the Holocene Epoch (that started 11700 years ago).

These periods of warming and cooling are triggered by the Melankovich cycles (these include eccentricity of the Earth's orbit, tilt of the earth's axis and precession of the Earth's axis)

These factors change cyclicly. Thus they produce cycles of glaciation when certain other factors are in place (eg. ocean currents...which are mostly determined by the position of continents. As well as feedback loops. Eg. exposed continental crust near polar regions covered in snow, reflecting sunlight. etc).

These state of conditions currently exist...and are responsible for the presence of ice caps. Which have been there for 2.6 million years. As long as those conditions exist and ice caps are present...we're still in an Ice Age.

text:
The most common prediction is that the AMOC weakens, resulting in more prevalent winter storms (especially in the UK) and more intense heat waves across Europe - and the South East of the UK. 


We've already seen both of these outcomes! - Intense cold and intense heat above the norms. 


So, you could argue - if this trend continues - it is no longer a prediction, but an eventuality. 


This doesn't mean an ice age, just more extremes as the earth warms.


There is another theory about the AMOC, which is completely against the grain of an ice age and cooling. Rather than the breakdown of the AMOC causing cooling, it could actually cause warming - less heat is carried down into the deep ocean, meaning the atmosphere gets warmer.


You know, if I was totally bat shit insane, I'd be so happy about the fact we're going to find out in our lifetimes which one is correct. But, not being crazier than a badger in a bag of bees, I'm not that stoked about witnessing which is correct. I really could do without this additional existential burden ... but hey, at least we'll be in it together, right ? ;)

text:
Nah. 

The onset of an Ice Age is caused by Jupiter tugging at the Earth causing it's orbit to become more eccentric. 

Global Climate is too complex to predict accurately. But the orbits of planets is the one critical factor in that complex equation we can at least predict with precision.

 2nd... we're already in an ice age...it started 2.6 million years ago and as long as continental glaciers exist, we're in an Ice Age. The freezing of the Earth part is called a period of glaciation.

Anyways, the glaciation period won't start before Jupiter does its thing.

Smaller cooling events are called Stadials (eg the little ice age...these don't last longer than 1000 years)

A period of Glaciation usually lasts about 90 thousand years.

The Average temprature I heard was 32¬∞F or something. If that was the average, if it dropped to 30¬∞F on average, that is an Ice Age technically.
The big ice that drags down here is not what describes an Ice Age apparently. It is how low the temperatures drop on average that causes it.
If our Average Temperature range of 32¬∞F dropped below to 29¬∞F average, that would cause a dramatic turn in how the Northern Hemisphere plays in and on weather behavior.
More snow, more ice, more killing of livestock due to freezing temperatures, and much more.

It got more heat-waves, more violent storms, more death due to heat, etc..
Now, take the Average Temperature for the Northern Hemisphere and drop it to 31¬∞F, and you would start seeing snow down in Oklahoma!
But, do not exclude the suns solar behavior and how warm ocean waters get at times, for Alaska got in the 90¬∞F temperature-range due to the ocean watee south of it got very warm, warmer than normal. Plus it was summer, so the solar influence also played a key role.
The Climate Change is on a variant influence. That is why it is hard to see if the next Ice Age is going to occur! Some places have gone from very cold to very hot, hotter than normal!
Time is a key, but the same goes with what we think has no influence, really initially does than we think.
One small change, leads to dramatic events that come forth after...

text:
Large, continental ice sheets in the Northern Hemisphere have grown and retreated many times in the past. We call times with large ice sheets ‚Äúglacial periods‚Äù (or ice ages) and times without large ice sheets ‚Äúinterglacial periods.‚Äù The most recent glacial period occurred between about 120,000 and 11,500 years ago. Since then, Earth has been in an interglacial period called the Holocene. Glacial periods are colder, dustier, and generally drier than interglacial periods. These glacial‚Äìinterglacial cycles are apparent in many marine and terrestrial paleoclimate records from around the world.
Source: NOAA

author: Brian Witt

text:
That's not really the best of ways to define it, but ... TECHNICALLY, it is still the ice age; the same one that's been going on for the last 2.6 million years, called the Quarternary period, wherein we've spent about 90% of the time under ice and about 10% with 'warn spells' like the one we're in now.  The positions of the continents and their influence on the directions ocean currents can take help define this pattern, and it's not likely to end for quite a while yet.  

In fact, prior to the near-doubling of carbon in the air in recent years pushing the world to uncharacteristic warmth, the general trend was cooling... back toward the 90% period of glaciation.  Humanity seems to be screwing that up, but it would be temporary.
author: J.E. Turcotte

text:
¬†@Donald Piniach¬† This is where I try to decide if that's even worth my time responding to.  Really, a picture of the last 200,000 years of pretty solid climate data would do, though... slight ups slight downs, waves of natural change within adaptable norms even through massive transitions from glaciation to warm spell and back.  And were you and actual climate scientists there the whole time it would be them saying 'watch out, this change may make crop yields not only change, but shift away from where folk presently live' and you'd be saying 'alarmist alarmist alarmist; it's a conspiracy!' and they'd be right and you'd be like 'as I said all along' and even talked yourself into believing it.  Trouble is, this time there's nothing natural about the shift.  The gradual changes that used to take generations not only are happening all at once, but to say it was happened with ten times the intensity, beyond anything seen in the fossil record short of asteroid impacts would be to understate the matter, and scientists have been warning us since the 1904 (not the 80s as you claim) and now folk are like 'nothing to see here, folks.'  

You've a lot of research to do for your own sake.  See 'feedback effects' and exponential math and a little thing called entropy, especially in regards to the sudden doubling of energy addition into an increasingly enclosed medium.  Hell... put two fish tanks on a sunny porch, one sealed with a big 'ol block of dry ice and both with thermometers, give 'em a while, and get back to us.  The thing with theories is they're based on observation of what's already happening, in an attempt to understand them.

The reason NY is colder than Europe at the same latitude has nothing to do with Gulf Stream but with the fact that in the northern hemisphere, the wind blows from West to East and NY is at the Eastern part of the USA which means in winter the air blows from Western USA to Eastern USA and as it does, it cools off and reaches NY much colder than on the Western side of the USA, where temperatures are similar to Western Europe.
Why do you think the coldest winter temperatures are in Eastern Siberia? Its again because the whole Asian continent cools off in winter and the air goes from West to East and when it reaches Eastern Siberia is at its coldest.
Similarly in summer, because the USA warms up, the East part of the USA is warmer than the Western USA.
Gulf Stream does absolutely nothing!  Its a myth.

text: No mention of the fact that the sun is the driver of climate change. We are entering into solar cycle 24 and there are less and less sunspots. Less sunspots means cooler sun. Less Coronal holes, means less solar wind, and an increase in cosmic rays which are directly linked with increased cloud formation. This cools the earth. Not denying the part the gulf stream plays in this, but man is not the cause. We need more CO2 Not less. Ice cores and tree rings show a huge plethora of CO2 in our atmosphere, way before man was ever a factor. This change is cyclical. A natural order. Basic science teaches that plants need CO2 to live. The lower the Co2 the more plants have to work to get it. Which means they lose more water, basically, they are drying out and becoming more flammable. Our atmosphere is currently sitting at  about 400  PPM.  Approx 200 or less is an extinction level event.  Think about that.  We are Entering a Grand Solar Minimum. Check out the work of Professor Valentina Zharkova and Nasa Scientist John Casey.  The Jet Streams are changing. Places that have been in drought now have rain and in some cases floods. Expect food shortages. Look at the Midwest US. Millions of acres unable to be planted due to the floods.  We are already seeing massive crop losses around the world and here. Many countries who have traditionally been exporters are now importers. Where is it going to come from?

text:
Anyone else notice the temperature illustration, about 2 minutes in, showing intense red over the Amazon rain forest and the jungles of mid-Africa? That's a total area easily equal twice the USA. 
Since there are virtually no official weather stations that are not inside the cement and asphalt of major cities in those locations, how does NASA obtain any reliable temperature records there, let alone temperatures higher than anywhere else?


The short answer is--they don't. They use computer models to guess at what the temperatures there WOULD BE GIVEN THAT THE CLIMATE MODELS ARE CORRECT AND THE GLOBAL TEMPERATURE IS ALWAYS RISING. 
They do the same thing with vast mid-ocean areas where there are little to no reliable temperature devices present.


Then they average all those manufactured high numbers in with the actual measured temperature readings, and presto--"It's another record high global temperature this year, folks".

author: percy higginbottom

text:
¬†@rick Fischer¬†    May i suggest some reading ?    - The Little Ice Age remains for the present the subject of speculation. The most likely influence during this period is variable output from the sun combined with pronounced volcanic activity. We know that from the end of the LIA to the 1950s the sun‚Äôs output increased. But since WW2 the sun has slowly grown quieter, yet the temperature on Earth has gone up.

The sceptical argument that current warming is a continuation of the same warming that ended the LIA is unlikely. There is a lack of evidence for a suitable forcing (e.g. the sun) and numerous correlations with known natural forcings that can account for the LIA itself, and the subsequent climate recovery. Taken in isolation, the LIA might cast doubt on the theory of climate change. Considered alongside the empirical evidence, model predictions and a century of scientific research into the climate, recovery from the LIA is not a plausible theory to explain the observed evidence and rate of global climate change-  https://skepticalscience.com/coming-out-of-little-ice-age.htm

author: Michael Painter

text:
¬†@Michael Painter¬† I work in Aquaculture and it amazes me how people think more CO2 is always a good thing for plants.

They don't understand nutrient requirements and depletion.

Studies have shown a short term benefit that quickly goes away as nutrients are depleted from the soil.

There are also studies that show crops grown in a higher CO2 environment are less nutritious.
author: Swirvin' Birds

text: ¬†@Swirvin' Birds¬† that makes sense as they don't have time to build up their internal chemistry even if fed enough and watered enough by a grower.
author: Michael Painter

text: ¬†@Swirvin' Birds¬† love aquaponics, the hydroponic store I worked at for a few years had nothing but aquaponics media bed displays except one which we never put high feeding plants in for cost savings reasons since hydro nutrients aren't cheap. Fish food is. Looking to incorporate that into my operation at some point.
author: Michael Painter

text:
¬†@Michael Painter¬† Personally I think aquaponics is the way of future farming. Self sustaining pretty much with 10% of the water usage of traditional farming as it's a recirculation system. Your basicly just replacing evoporated water. Fish waste feeds the plants and the plants can feed the fish as well depending on what you are growing. We are using tillapia and when the fish get too big you can cull it and have your protein to go with the veggies. We haven't done that yet as it's not a commercial set-up (1,000 gallon tank) and they are kinda more like pets. Lol

We are still in the 1st year of our little set-up and we are still trying to work out a few kinks in the system but for a student led and built project it's been going pretty good. Learning a lot and still a lot to learn.
We have had the same nutrient depletion in the water as well. We have been spraying the leaves with Iron and such but we are currently looking into other options.

My main job is raising salmon and trout. Farming of a different kind... :)
author: Swirvin' Birds

text: ¬†@Swirvin' Birds¬† in the shop we were doing tilapia, catfish and started messing with koi. While the koi aren't normally eaten their resilience to freezing temperatures made then quite useful for outdoor set ups. Those fish apparently produce alcohol in the winter as anti freeze which I found hilarious. Spend all winter drunk essentially. Catfish could be tricky as at about 2 years old they will literally gobble up everything else in the tanks so they had to be pulled out. Now they are good eating.
author: Michael Painter

text: ¬†@Swirvin' Birds¬† add a worm farm and it's possible to make it a closed loop system. I don't like bell syohons because they clog but they don't run on power which is nice. Fun stuff.
author: Michael Painter

text:
¬†@Michael Painter¬† that's awesome! I have 3 channel cats in another tank with some bluegill but never thought of putting them in the aquaponics tank. Sounds like it's good I didn't.

Those KOI don't sound too different from us humans after all!!üòÑ

text:
"New" Ice Age? We haven't left the old one yet. We are just in a small interglacial that comes around every 100,000 years or so, that the glaciers will advance at some point in the future is a given. You might also want to consider that the average trend over the last 8,000 years is down. While the planet warms and cools every thousand years or so, the fact is that each peak is lower than the one before and each trough is deeper than the one before. The coldest part of the "Little Ice Age" is arguably the coldest the planet has been in over 8,000 years.


But we are still in a planetary Ice Age and when the temps drop we will not be able to stop it. Moscow, Berlin, Paris, Scotland, Scandinavia and Canada will once again be under a mile or two of ice.

text: Looks like Ol' Sol is beginning his nap. This on happens about every 400 years. It's called a "Grand Solar Minimum". This is not man made and there is absolutely nothing to be done for it. author: JohnJ469

text:
¬†@JohnJ469¬†...I think the last interglacial was 20 thousand years (also, it spiked 2 degrees Celsius higher than the current interglacial has... So far, at least.  

The average interglacial is 15 thousand years... Glacials and interglacials are triggered when Jupiter tugs at our orbit and puts the earth in circular or elliptical orbits. The elliptical orbits last about 95 thousand years (hence the reason glaciation lasts 95 thousand years)... The circular orbits last 15 thousand years until Jupiter's next tug (hence the reason interglacials last 15 thousand years on average) 

All of that only applies if the right conditions exist (as they do today). Antartica being the main culprit in this story.

The current interglacial is expected to be an unusually long one (regardless of human intervention)....hence the reason my estimate is 5 to 10 thousand years (which is actually a modest estimate).
author: Tyler Durden

text:
¬†@Tyler Durden¬† Not to be argumentative, but where are you getting your data from? We exited the last glaciation about 15k years bp. (Ignoring the Younger Dryas). The previous interglacials were at about 110k year intervals and none of the last 3 lasted anywhere near 15k years. The last interglacial to last as long as the current one was 410k years bp and it only lasted 10k years.


I'm going by the Vostok ice cores which simply do not show what you are describing. AFAIK these are pretty definitive, so if you have data that contradicts them, I'd like to see it. And I have seen estimates that this interglacial will last 50k years. I doubt this simply because the average temperatures have been dropping for the last 8k years. The bottom of the "Little Ice Age", circa 1800 was the coldest the planet has been in about 8,000 years.


While temps go up and down over a thousand years or so, the pattern has been that each peak is lower than the last and each trough has been colder than the last. Our current warming has not reached the Medieval Warm period temperatures yet, the MWP was cooler than the Roman Warm Period which in turn was cooler than the Minoan Warm Period. The trend is definitely down.
author: JohnJ469

text: The ice age ended 11,000 years ago.
author: epicrotfl

text:
¬†@epicrotfl¬† Actually it didn't. We entered the most recent "Interglacial" around 11,000 years ago but the Era we are in is still an "Ice Age".


It hasn't been a series of Ice Ages, but a single "Ice Age" with a warm "Interglacial" about every 100,000 years or so. 90%+ of the last 2 million years has been Ice Age and when this Interglacial ends we will go back to those conditions.


People think that warm is normal and an Ice Age is unusual, but in reality the Ice is normal and we are just very, very lucky to be living in a rare, long warm period. Just because it's a warm day doesn't mean that Winter is over.
author: JohnJ469

text: JohnJ469 there‚Äôs a lot of conflicting sources on this topic, but I looked into it more after I said that.
author: epicrotfl

text:
¬†@epicrotfl¬† Don't sweat it. I used to regularly say "After the Ice Age ended....." until I did a heap of reading. That's when I realised that everything I had been taught in school was the reverse of reality.


Saying the Ice Age ended implies that warm is here to stay and that isn't so. We're still in the Ice Age and will be so for a long time yet. 


But hey, I'm still learning too. Coming into the warm period might be the reason we have agriculture and civilisation. Humans like us evolved over 100k years ago and yet did virtually nothing development wise until 10k years ago. If you look at the Greenland cores the temps really went wild in each Glacial, it's only in the Interglacial they've been steady enough to develop crops, etc.


The Anthropology and Archaeology of ancient climates is really interesting.

author: wes c

text:
¬†@wes c¬† No problem! 
Here is an example of link for albedo: https://eosweb.larc.nasa.gov/project/misr/gallery/global_albedo_seasonal


I don't know much about GCR. However I can tell you this: clouds are atmospheric humidity (water vapor) transformed into water liquid or water solid. 
To transform water from liquid to vapor state, energy is taken, - when evaporation occur at the ocean, or on land, it is cooling the environment. This energy is later on released in the atmosphere, when water vapor transforms into liquid or solid. 
Anyway the point here is: there can only be as much clouds as there is water vapor in the atmosphere. GCR won't create clouds out of nowhere. 


I saw on article on GCR but I could tell it was a weird article as it was denying atmospheric CO2 is increasing - something that we have measured accurately for years. Do you have a reference for an article about GCR and clouds? 


About the sun cycle, it is an easy exercise to answer your question. (clouds are much more complicated). 
Remember the equation on wikipedia: 


(1-a)S=4 e s T^4


you can easily calculate equilibrium T from this. I'll do it for you: 
S = 1367; % Solar constant
a = 0.3; % Earth average albedo
s = 5.67e-8; % Stefan-Boltzmann constant
e = 0.612; % Effective emissivity of earth


T = ((1-a)*S/(4*e*s))^(1/4) - 273.15 = 15 (degree C)


now if you google solar cycle, look for images, you'll see the value of S varying between 1367 and 1365 (W m-2)
if I use S = 1365 I get: 


T = ((1-a)*S/(4*e*s))^(1/4) - 273.15 = 14.9 (degree C)


As you can see... that's not a big change. The solar cycle doesn't have a big impact on Earth climate (but milankovitch cycle does!! but on much longer time scale.)


In the equation, what has changed and continue to change is global albedo (a) and the effective emissivity of Earth. 


If e was 1 (without atmospheric CO2), we would have: 
e= 1;


T = ((1-a)*S/(4*e*s))^(1/4) - 273.15 = -18.3 (degree C)


33 degree C colder! So it's a good thing we have some CO2 in the atmosphere. 
now, if the effective emissivity of Earth was 0, that would mean that all heat is trapped on earth... at 0, the temperature would just keep increasing (there is no T equilibrium, because there's only heat going in, and no heat going out - T keeps increasing). 


On some planet, such as Venus, there is a lot of greenhouse gas, causing T to be very high. Average temperature on Venus is 462 degree C. 


In the next 2 or 3 decades, global temperature will probably continue to rise, as CO2 will increase and trap more heat. 


Read this one, I think it explains things pretty well! https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/features/EnergyBalance

text:
So wait:
If our climate get warmer, ice starts melting from Greenland and the poles.
We know that ocean water circulation works on a temperature/saltyness factor. Water gets warmer at the equator, evaporating faster than at the poles, and therefore being more salty.
This salty water is more dense than average water, but also warmer, allowing it to float at the surface. The water drifts form the equator to the poles (for a more complicated reason, that will be left out), loosing its heat on the way. As it cooles down, but by keeping the same density, it starts to drown through underwater waterfall currents. Also because of temperature, some water gets trapped into Ice (maybe the reason why it gets pulled to  the poles in the first place?).
Anway, water sinks, goes to the south, comes back up, and does the route again.


What happens if we warm the wind temperatures?
Ice at the poles melt, letting go of more "pure" unsalinated water. This mixes with over-salinated water, changing its density, and stopping it from drowning back again.
If this current stops, cold water won't flow back to the equator, not cooling the land on its way, removing a temperature stabilisator phenomena at the same time.


So although the poles get hoter, the waters get less salty, and more "floaty".


But if the equator get hoter, more wind turbulances will occure. The land in between the poles and the equator might not get wamredup as much for the waters, but maybe hoter from the winds. We will get more into the extremes, and have less "stable" climates.


Am I right?

text:
I wish that non-scientists would stop making alarmist videos. 

the wild assumption is that man is altering the atmosphere with CO2.  well, we know that is total false because of all the historically hotter times the planet has endured with much lower CO2
we also know that sea water releases CO2 when it is heated. 

we also know (and here is where you home science proves the errors)   we know that ice regulates temperature.  put ice in a glass and your drink stays cold as long as the ice is in the glass.
once the ice melts, the temperature soar quickly.   less ice, rising temperature... get the connection ?   warmer sea water more CO2, get the connection ?
the last time we had so little arctic sea ice was at the end of the 1800's when fisherman and scientists were afraid that all the sea ice would vanish and it was as high as 90 degrees above the arctic circle and the permfrost melted making mud.
Please also check your map,  warm can only come from either the sun or wind.  for Europe to be warm, the prevailing winds would have to come from the sea.  then over mountains to heat up other areas.  your video only allows for coastal temperatures.

text:
Good Questions!


When seawater freezes, it typically freezes slowly enough that water forms crystalline structures which do not leave space for the salt molecules to remain. This is why icebergs and glaciers contain freshwater. 

You are right in the sense that ice already in the ocean does not contribute to rising sea levels. But the point of this video is to describe how current climate change patterns causing the melting of ice in the Artic lead to an Ice Age, causing higher temperatures near the equator and lower temperatures near the north.  The rising sea levels is also an issue but not caused by melting ice already in the ocean. It is a separate issue related climate change, but would also still occur in conjunction with another ice age.

Hopefully that answers your questions, if you have anymore i'd be happy to try and help answer them.

text:
To exit an interglacial CO2 slowly gets to 245ppm over 12,000-15,000 years where cooling speeds up, below 200ppm full glacials begin.

The extreme rains causing flooding and deep snow are from the planet moving cold south to cool the equator only over land, oceans are too warm.

We're at 496ppm CO2 equivalent all gases, give up on ice ages, we're already back to the Early Pliocene, sea-level hundreds of feet higher, oh joy.

Recall the Miocene was warmer, CO2 higher than the Pliocene, which was warmer CO2 higher than the Pleistocene when CO2 was finally low enough for astronomical forcing to begin causing ice ages, rearranged land masses also involved.

The first ice ages were regular at 41,000-years, as CO2 continued to decline from the rising Himalaya this whole time removing it via rock erosion, the more complex 100,000-year cycles began ...

The only large study of glaciers in N.America put a 60-year max on them as a water supply, dams will be useless on only seasonal rain.

There is the electric exchange in the upper atmosphere through Birkeland currents and another more simple electrical contact by plasma Which sends sprite electric storms above the clouds. This plasma and electric contact generate electromagnetic fields which influence the jet stream. Climate change is very, very complicated If a volcano erupts in Greenland It will melt everything it touches thousands of tons of ice will melt it will warm up that melted water is that part of the model not it is not, yet Antartica has 99 newly discovered volcanoes. text:
It's called global because it describes the change in the average temperature of the entire world. Hence global and not local. Still, if the climate gets stuck in an upward spiral of self-reinforcing warming where melting permafrost releases more greenhouse gases and making it even warmer globally and so on, eventually you'll get hot again. The earth has had periods in the past when CO2 levels we're so high and the earth so warm basically everything was rainforest or deserts and there was no ice left even at the poles, and even the poles were green because of the massive amounts of floating algae was growing there, look up the carboniferous period for example. The thing is rainforest can't come out of nowhere though, it needs time to spread and build up, so if the climate warms too fast, i.e. over mere decades or centuries instead of tens or hundreds of thousands of years, you just get desert and no rainforest to regulate the climate and everything is far hotter and drier than it would have been naturally in the past at that CO2 level.

The point is, global warming will fuck human civilization up.

text: Climate Change as words is generally so stupid vague it isn't funny!! To start with the climate is ALWAYS changing, in winter we have cold weather, and the climate changes to reflect that we are in fact further away from the sun in "that time of the year" when we have "winter"!! Equally in summer months the earth tilts TOWARDS the sun in some areas making the summer months warmer or even hotter depending on the SEASON and the angle of the earth to the sun....and again as you can guess the "climate changes" to reflect this event!! The honest truth to this is the earth and sun have been doing this for millions of years, summer hot, winter cold depending WHERE on the planet you are at what time of the year!! So "dumbing down" "global warming" to calling it "climate change" is even more stupid that realizing the earth warms and cools at different rates in different parts of the world depending on how the earth is angled towards or away from the sun!! That in mind it is June here in Upstate New York and just weeks ago our temperature during night time hours hit 35 degrees (F) (Or 1.6 degrees (C)) and keep in mind THIS IS JUNE which is the beginning of summer here in the Northeast!! So explain to me how it can be so cold in a "global warming" temperature swing?!

This is a October 2003, Pentagon report on climate. "An Abrupt Climate Change Scenario and it's Implications for United States National Security" http://www.documentcloud.org/documents/18341-an-abrupt-climate-change-scenario-and-its-implications-for-us-national-security.html
It's not you or Co2. It's the Sun. The Sun goes through different cycles of Maximums, and Minimums. When the Sun was at Maximum it melted a lot of polar ice that desalinated the North Atlantic and Pacific ocean. The BP Oil spill clogged up the Gulf Stream, and those two events weakened the AMOC. There is no more warm equitorial Currents into Northern Europe. Go to windy.com and click on Currents. This skipped sea level rise.
   The Sun is in what is called a Grand Solar Minimum. Global Warming leads to global cooling, but the Earth will not be in an ice age till about 2050. However, it's the crop losses which we all must prepare for now. This is Ice Age Farmer's crop loss map. iceagefarmer.com/map

text:
It needs to be pointed out that the temperatures at the poles are increasing much faster than the rest of the earth's surface.  


There is a huge northward flow of water in the Atlantic that originates in the sea around Antarctica that is showing some slowing of water flowing north from there which meets the Gulf Stream.  I can't find a reference or citation on that, but have read that from several sources.  One of the reasons the term Global Warming was dropped in favor of Climate Change is that Great Britain is likely to get colder due to changes in the Gulf Stream.  


The size of the minimum summer ice layer on the Arctic Ocean is not only getting much smaller, the thickness of it has declined faster than its shrinkage in size.  That is causing greater oscillation in the northern jet stream, which seems to be causing colder weather in the eastern U.S.  I first read about this change in oscillation causing the eastern states cool down about 25-30 years ago so I viewed the national news coverage of the winters back there with perhaps a different perspective than a lot of people.   


I first read about a cool down in store for western northern Europe about 10-15 years ago so I'm watching the news on BBC with that in mind.  


Your audio sounds like it is over modulating.  Whatever it is I now have a headache after listening to it.

text:
‚Äã¬†@Sue Young¬† Even if you were right about solar cycles being the sole cause of climate change, you're defeating your own narrative by saying there's no such thing as global warming. If you are right about your second statement (solar cycles), then you are wrong about your first statement (there's no such thing as global warming) because your second statement claims global warming is real (and caused by solar cycles).
I'm no expert on the whole 'solar cycle' thing, so I'm gonna assume solar activity does play a role in climate change (though Earth's shielding mechanisms are pretty damn good, so I'm gonna go with 'it's but a relatively small effect'), but if we look at the earth's history, then activities of life have played a monumental role in causing climate change through chemical atmospheric alteration. Human activity incorporates machines that add to that, while we've also (in the past) been stripping Earth from mechanisms that lock atmospheric greenhouse chemicals down (trees, for example). 
The anthropogenic element to climate change is but one of many, it's absolutely true, but if you take a bucket, put it under a dripping tap, wait until it's nearly full, and then pour half a liter of water on top of that, then denying that that half a liter of water had any influence in the bucket overflowing is just nonsense. Yes, that bucket would have overflowed eventually, but the reason it overflowed now, and with such sudden volatility, is your addition of half a liter of water.

author: Roland Deschain

text:
¬†@Roland Deschain¬† You shouldn't link things you don't understand. A winshield not heating up as much as a carhood does not violate thermodynamics. A windshield simply does not obstruct as much light as a carhood. Therefore, it converts less energy from light to heat than a carhood does. This is not difficult. This is not top-tier science. This is the stuff 11-year olds learn in school.
Ice doesn't heat up as fast as basalt in sunlight, because ice reflects far more sunlight than basalt.


If we create an atmosphere that does not lose heat quickly, then heat (from the sun, yes) will accumulate on the planet faster, simply because the atmosphere traps more of it. Just like a blanket doesn't warm you up; it merely traps your bodyheat.


'Climate Change' is a complicated issue; in part, it's weather changes due to deforestation and desertification, in part it's weather changes due to increased temperatures affecting the oceans. And the latter are because emissions have been thickening the planet's 'blanket,' so that more of the heat that reaches our planet is retained for longer.

¬†@zack risen¬† And again someone telling us all to 'go to school' when they do not have the faintest idea about climate.
The sun does not control climate; it merely inputs energy into climate systems. Those climate systems do not respond uniformly, because every climate system is different.
If you punch a slab of gypsum and a slab of meat, both slabs are going to behave differently from on another; your punch merely imparts energy to the slabs.
Change the slab, and you change how it responds to the punch.

text: Not by individual choices we can't. It is simply a fallacy to think that you can moralize your way out of a problem created by collective activity. The reality is this problem can only be solved top-down, through concerted collective efforts of entire nations. You cannot solve climate change through a change in what you consume, nearly every product and every service you use is part of a long chain of production which relies on activity that is exacerbating climate change. You cannot as an individual stop the CO2 output by megacorporations in industry and agriculture and transport. All you can do is vote for a government that will pass laws to stop these things, that will direct vast amounts of manpower and resources to undertake a change toward a sustainable infrastructure and economy. Individual activity is only a small fraction of the problem and you won't make a dent in the CO2 output even if everyone went vegan overnight and only ever used public transport, because the majority of the CO2 is produced by industry. The corporations have to be forced at gunpoint to change the way they operate because they will never do it of their own volition, no company will willingly sacrifice profits for their shareholders unless the government makes them. Hence the need to take political power and control the army. Capitalism will never stop climaten change of its own accord, it's the reason why we're in this shit in the first place. China is doing it right, they keep capitalism on a tight leash, strictly controlled by the state and they're making the biggest strides toward green, renewable energy of any country in the world.

author: John Peric

text:
¬†@John Peric¬† I wholeheartedly disagree about the water levels not being a threat, we've already had to evacuate cities. Plus, projections rate that sea level rise to speed up immensely. Also, 1 meter of rise alone could throw a ton of coastal cities underwater.

As for the habitable planets, perhaps my figures are out of date? I'm not using the Earth's current status when I make that claim (being in an ice age and all) I'm using its position to the sun.
author: Storywalker4

text:
¬†@Storywalker4¬† 
It isn't a threat, and what cities have we had to evacuate? Please, enlighten me.

Lastly, 1 meter of sea level rise isn't threatening, especially when it occurs over a span of 285 years. 

Even Miami Beach wouldn't be threatened, at our current rate it would take 400 years for Miami to regularly flood during extreme high tides.

Also, sea levels could do a lot of things, we don't know, all our ice sheets could melt in 30 years, or they could drop 110 meters by 2100. Scientist aren't prophets. So I'm going to base it off current rates, because the current rate is all we know.

Lastly before sea level rises 1 meter our current warm phase will have probably ended.

Edit: also 150 million people live 1 meter or less above the high tide mark. That's a lot of people, but it's over a 285 year time period, or just 1442 people migrating every day.

And most of the fruit and vegetable crops of the EU. 


Because of the jet streams and other wind patterns from being on a rotating planet, only Europe gets hit by the cold, meaning N. American coasts get to burn while Europe freezes to death. 


The equatorial regions see a mild increase of 1/6th the temperature increases at the poles, also due to the spinning globe transporting all the  latent heat in the evaporating ocean waters, towards the poles. 


The only time that North Atlantic conveyor belt shuts down is if a very large chunk of land ice actually breaks off of Greenland and plops into the ocean. This is probably why there is conflicting data sets on if that conveyor is shutting down. text:
Information I've seen shows the Medieval Warm Period (MWP) to have been as warm or warmer than today. What caused the end of the MWP and the beginning of the Little Ice Age (LIA) is up for debate and the two leading contenders I've seen for what caused it to end are volcanic activity and solar activity. The coldest period of the LIA began in the 1600s, by which time solar activity was being monitored, so we know that in the 1600s solar activity decreased greatly and entered what called a Grand Solar Minimum. This grand solar minimum is referred to as the Maunder Minimum named after the scientist who was measuring daily solar activity at that time. In 1815 the eruption of Mount Tambora caused a volcanic winter which lasted for a number of years and caused the year without a summer in 1816. After the effects of the Tambora eruption subsided the earth began to warm until the 1940s when a global cooling trend began which lasted until the the late 1970s. This is why in the 1970s many scientists and some government agencies were concerned about or predicting the beginning of a new ice age. Here are a couple of examples of the kind of news articles I was reading in the 1970s and what I was seeing on TV.

U.S. and Soviet Press Studies of a Colder Arctic
"The United States and the Soviet Union are mounting large‚Äêscale investigations to determine why the Arctic climate is becoming more frigid, why parts of the Arctic sea ice have recently become ominously thicker and whether the extent of that ice cover contributes to the onset of ice ages."
https://www.nytimes.com/1970/07/18/archives/us-and-soviet-press-studies-of-a-colder-arctic-us-and-soviet-press.html

The Cooling World 

"Climatologists are pessimistic that political leaders will take any positive action to compensate for the climatic change, or even to allay its effects. They concede that some of the more spectacular solutions proposed, such as melting the Arctic ice cap by covering it with black soot or diverting arctic rivers, might create problems far greater than those they solve."
http://www.wmconnolley.org.uk/sci/iceage/newsweek-coolingworld.pdfClimatologists are

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L_861us8D9M

Beginning in the 1970s solar activity began to increase causing NASA's Skylab to crash to earth earlier than expected and by the late 1970s/1980s cooling had stopped and warming began. 

"Greater-than-expected solar activity heated the outer layers of Earth's atmosphere and increased drag on Skylab. By late 1977, NORAD also forecast a reentry in mid-1979; a National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) scientist criticized NASA for using an inaccurate model for the second most-intense sunspot cycle in a century, and for ignoring NOAA predictions published in 1976."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skylab


In the 1980s and 90s solar activity increased to the highest level seen in modern times and is called the Modern Solar Maximum. In the early 2000s solar activity began to decrease which caused the global warming pause. Since the early 2000s there has been no "significant" warming and the small amount of warming that has occurred is far below the predictions made by climate models. Based on the paleoclimate record grand solar minimums occur about every 400 years and the last grand solar minimum occurred 400 years ago. The last two 11-year solar cycles have seen a huge decrease in solar activity which mirrors the solar activity seen at the beginning of the Maunder Minimum in the 1600s. 

Here is a BBC report from 2015 about the decreasing solar activity:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DueVWamHmYs

Here is a news article from 2018: The Chill of Solar Minimum - As 2018 comes to an end, the Thermosphere Climate Index is on the verge of setting a Space Age record for Cold. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not there quite yet,‚Äù says Mlynczak, ‚Äúbut it could happen in a matter of months.‚Äù
https://spaceweatherarchive.com/2018/09/27/the-chill-of-solar-minimum/

Here is a documentary about the Little Ice Age: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vZFXZ0bATyc

By the way, during the Little Ice Age witchcraft and Satan were blamed for climate change. In this round of climate change Satan is no longer blamed but humans still are.

text:
The amount off water that poured into the North Atlantic from Meltwater Pulse 1A, was enough to rise sea level 30m in less than a thousand years. If the Greenland ice sheet melted it would only rise sea 7.2m. Not enough to stop the ocean current. 

The Little Ice Age was caused by a Grand Solar Minimum called the Maunder Minimum. A weakened solar magnetic field leaves the earth more susceptible to cosmic rays penetrating our lower atmosphere. Cosmic rays initiate nucleation, which is how clouds form. With more cloud cover reflecting sunlight, the planet cools. 

The jet-streams in our upper atmosphere which keep the cold air at the poles, also seem to be affected by GSM. They become more wavy and events like the Polar Vortex, which America experienced this year, can happen more often. 

The U.S. has just gone through it's coldest wettest winter in a hundred years. There are huge crop losses not only in the U.S., but worldwide because of the cold weather. This is because we are in a very weak cycle of solar activity right now. Many solar physicists are calling it the start of another Grand Solar Minimum. 

Don't take my word for it though. Do some research.
