text:
Not all studies are created equal that being said you're leaving out a massive piece of the puzzle and by you're I mean climatologists but since the piece of the puzzle they're leaving out is outside of their wheelhouse it's almost understandable I mean they're climatologists not solar physicists

Let me go ahead and jump in here and say that there are a million and one reasons why we need to stop poisoning our planet and things need to be done about that immediately if not sooner with that being said

To clarify what I mean here let me preface this by saying the 90 something percent of climate scientists agree that climate change is real and man-made line of bullshit the news media tries to feed us comes from a single conglomerate study that's a decade-old that only counted scientific papers put out by climatologists at the time that took a hardcore stance on whether or not climate change was man-made and real if the paper did not take a stance either way or only took a stance on either it being real or it being man-made they were not included so the end result only included roughly 30% of the climate papers available at the time a decade ago

Since then the bread and butter of securing funding for further research for climatologists has been anything having to do with climate change and this has resulted in some dishonesty cherry picking of results and poor interpretations a lot of times just by leaving out highly significant variables

Most climate papers studies and ergo the simulations and predictions based on them only count one type of solar forcing and that is UV exposure which only counts a 4% variance in irradiance which is negligible and occasionally you'll find a study that factors in sunspot variability when in reality there is closer to a dozen different types of solar forcing and many of the other types have a vastly greater impact on our planet and When taking into account they paint a entirely different picture as to why our climate has been changing

There is one significant piece of evidence that is counted as scientific fact Undisputed and simultaneously somehow has flown under the radar of climatologists whether intentionally or by accident and that is the fact that every planet in our solar system has experienced a significant change in climate during the same time periods as Earth knowing that fact you can realize that either somehow driving your car here on Earth affects the temperature of every planet in the solar system or these solar system-wide changes in climate are being caused by something that affects the solar system as a whole and there is only one thing that can do that and that's the Sun.
 has the sun been doing anything interesting during this period Of time possibly something that correlates with the observation that every planet in the Solar System's climate has experienced a significant change yes there is the Sun goes through Cycles where it is more and less active and while most people are familiar with the seven-year sunspot cycle they are unaware of the larger 400-year activity cycle known as the grand solar maximum Grand solar minimum cycle and if we look at geological evidence and historic records of the climate 400 years ago we come across a time in our history known as the maunder minimum sometimes nicknamed the mini ice age

I know what you're thinking you're thinking but the climate is getting hotter not colder but let me tell you that's the thing the way the solar Cycles work you hit the peak of grand solar maximum right before the start of grand solar minimum and in 2018 the sun started going long periods of time without a single sunspot currently the sun is so inactive that the number of sunspots as of June 4th 2019 hasn't exceeded double-digits in the preceding decades it was not uncommon to have literally hundreds of sunspots on the sun simultaneously

The other problem with the man-made climate change argument is the fact that greenhouse gases compose of 0.1% of our atmosphere and of that 0.1% carbon dioxide only accounts for 4% and of that carbon dioxide Mankind's contribution accounts for 3.4%
So just for emphasis the whole of Mankind's contribution to greenhouse gases in the atmosphere in total is 3.4% of 4% of 0.1%

That's so small of an amount it's ridiculous to think that it has even the faintest hope of changing the average temperature by even one one hundredth of a degree that's like putting a drop of boiling water into a swimming pool and thinking it's going to change the temperature

There's a YouTube channel that has a video series on this it goes into far more detail the name of the channel is Suspicious Observers if you need any references they provide plenty

text:
Climate Change: How Do We Know based on the comparison of atmospheric samples contained in ice cores and more recent direct  measurements, provides evidence that atmospheric CO2 has increased  since the Industrial Revolution. based on the comparison of atmospheric samples contained in ice cores and more recent direct measurements, provides evidence that atmospheric CO2 has increased since the Industrial Revolution. 

The Earth's climate has changed throughout history. Just in the last 650,000 years there have been seven cycles of glacial advance and retreat, with the abrupt end of the last ice age about 7,000 years ago marking the beginning of the modern climate era ‚Äî and of human civilization. Most of these climate changes are attributed to very small variations in Earth‚Äôs orbit that change the amount of solar energy our planet receives.

Scientific evidence for warming of the climate system is unequivocal.
- Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
The current warming trend is of particular significance because most of it is extremely likely (greater than 95 percent probability) to be the result of human activity since the mid-20th century and proceeding at a rate that is unprecedented over decades to millennia.1

Earth-orbiting satellites and other technological advances have enabled scientists to see the big picture, collecting many different types of information about our planet and its climate on a global scale. This body of data, collected over many years, reveals the signals of a changing climate.

The heat-trapping nature of carbon dioxide and other gases was demonstrated in the mid-19th century.2 Their ability to affect the transfer of infrared energy through the atmosphere is the scientific basis of many instruments flown by NASA. There is no question that increased levels of greenhouse gases must cause the Earth to warm in response.

Ice cores drawn from Greenland, Antarctica, and tropical mountain glaciers show that the Earth‚Äôs climate responds to changes in greenhouse gas levels. Ancient evidence can also be found in tree rings, ocean sediments, coral reefs, and layers of sedimentary rocks. This ancient, or paleoclimate, evidence reveals that current warming is occurring roughly ten times faster than the average rate of ice-age-recovery warmin

The evidence for rapid climate change is compelling:
Global Temperature Rise
The planet's average surface temperature has risen about 2.0 degrees Fahrenheit (1.1 degrees Celsius) since the late 19th century
The planet's average surface temperature has risen about 1.62 degrees Fahrenheit (0.9 degrees Celsius) since the late 19th century, a change driven largely by increased carbon dioxide and other human-made emissions into the atmosphere.4 Most of the warming occurred in the past 35 years, with the five warmest years on record taking place since 2010. Not only was 2016 the warmest year on record, but eight of the 12 months that make up the year ‚Äî from January through September, with the exception of June ‚Äî were the warmest on record for those respective months. 5

Warming Oceans
The oceans have absorbed much of this increased heat, with the top 700 meters (about 2,300 feet) of ocean showing warming of more than 0.4 degrees Fahrenheit since 1969.
The oceans have absorbed much of this increased heat, with the top 700 meters (about 2,300 feet) of ocean showing warming of more than 0.4 degrees Fahrenheit since 1969.6

Shrinking Ice Sheets
The Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets have decreased in mass
The Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets have decreased in mass. Data from NASA's Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment show Greenland lost an average of 286 billion tons of ice per year between 1993 and 2016, while Antarctica lost about 127 billion tons of ice per year during the same time period. The rate of Antarctica ice mass loss has tripled in the last decade



Glacial Retreat
Glaciers are retreating almost everywhere around the world ‚Äî including in the Alps, Himalayas, Andes, Rockies, Alaska and Africa.
Glaciers are retreating almost everywhere around the world ‚Äî including in the Alps, Himalayas, Andes, Rockies, Alaska and Africa.8

Decreased Snow Cover
Satellite observations reveal that the amount of spring snow cover in the Northern Hemisphere has decreased over the past five decades and that the snow is melting earlier
Satellite observations reveal that the amount of spring snow cover in the Northern Hemisphere has decreased over the past five decades and that the snow is melting earlier.9
+ MORE
Sea Level Rise
Global sea level rose about 8 inches in the last century. The rate in the last two decades, however, is nearly double that of the last century and is accelerating slightly every year
Global sea level rose about 8 inches in the last century. The rate in the last two decades, however, is nearly double that of the last century and is accelerating slightly every year.

text: I prefer excess cold to excess heat personally. In the first place, I'm Canadian myself. I'm used to it. In the second place, you can get away from cold easier than you can get away from heat. Staving off cold is just a matter of good preparation, but heat? Heat follows you. It seeps into everything. Sure, I could take a cold bath, but then I can't be productive. And if I don't, I'm sweaty and thirsty and uncomfortable all day (and night), so I still can't be as productive. Thermodynamics is a bitch, eh? And as a bonus--maybe this is personal preference, maybe it's my Canadian-ness--I find that I prefer large, dangerous animals to things like bugs or snakes or what have you. Maybe it has something to do with the fact that the former category of creature has a lot more trouble inviting itself into my house. The leggy bois show up whenever they want at this time of year, making me disgusted if not quite afraid, but in the winter, which is a good two-thirds of the year around here, they mercifully fuck off. To each their own, but I prefer winter to summer most of the time.
author: Alex Hodge

text:
Yes the sun plays an influence but CO2 is a Greenhouse Gas.¬†
Greenhouse Gases remain in the layer of our atmosphere called the stratosphere. When the sun hits us with heat, usually a lot of the heat will dissipate into space but with increased Greenhouse Gas concentrations, the heat is trapped in the Earths atmosphere raising average global temperatures up.

In the Carboniferous period of Earth's history (360 -300 million years ago) there was a MUCH higher CO2 concentration (3-5 times what it is now) which led to temperatures about 14 degrees Fahrenheit (8 Celsius) higher than what they were today.

The sun 360-300 million years ago was almost the same as it is know and thousands of solar cycles occurred during the period. Solar cycles will influence climate but they do not influence it by as much a margin as greenhouse gases.

text: While scientifically in the voodoo stone age, at least this video reflects, in all the wrong ways, what is happening. Unlike the cult of climate, the data here will, for all the wrong reasons, provide some degree of accuracy in predicting future climate. For those with the guts to face the truth, mankind was never the driver of climate. The climate already had a reputation for change long before man and like all anthropocentric thinking, man has over assumed itself as the only source of change. In fact, it was changing long before us, and if you follow the changes, you will find no deviation from historic trend has occurred (something that surprisingly, a few people have trouble swallowing). There is a yet bigger picture of cause and effect in and around Earth's environment, the details of which comprise the next major scientific era. But in short, the poles generate cold. The equator generates heat. Warm and cold eras are built on which one gets to transport it's temp over most of earth's surface. So in the depth of an ice age, the equator will be cooler, in a hot house Earth, the poles warmer. There is no greenhouse effect because there is no trapping of the heat like in a greenhouse. The entire "greenhouse effect" is built on a very low IQ. Right now, a cold era is dominating in total contradiction to global warming theory. That is why, in the US, we just had the coldest spring ever in US history. A lot of rain is occurring because warm air is being hit with cold that knocks the moisture right out of the air,... just like how every cold era starts. As is expected of a sleeping scientific community more concerned with money and existential affairs, the scientific community will shake it's voodoo dolls at the sky and tell us the cold is wild and out of control, a human caused threat. Never mind that the cold will entirely abate by 2045 back into a warm era where a new pseudo science will claim it is all our fault yet again.

author: Transsylvanian

text:
¬†@Transsylvanian¬† I both agree and disagree with you there. The idea that capitalism requires infinite growth isn't entire true. Rather, more truth would lie, if you ask me, in the assumption that the kind of world economy we are currently enjoying is not, strictly speaking, capitalist. 
Capitalism occurs when two parties trade objects, and both parties consider themselves to have gained more worth than they lost. For example: A hunter trades a deer for an axe at the flinter. The flinter, who has worked to create the axe, values a deer more than the hunter, who is in need of a new axe. In this transaction, worth is created in excess by the experience of value of both participants. This is the sense in which capitalism has a theoretically infinite ability to generate wealth through worth, through essentially people's perception of the value of products.


What is happening currently, however, is an upper class who siphons that value out of the overall economy. 
An example here is investment and shares. Shares were initially created so that entrepreneurs could create businesses that were too large for the entrepreneurs to  afford. They did this by selling shares of the future profit to people; people would buy those shares, and in return would (eventually) get profit, while the entrepreneur would now have a vast sum of money to invest.
The problem is that those who held those shares would then sell those shares to other people; the stock market. Every time a share is sold for a profit, a bit of that share's value disappears in the profit that is made. 
When the top % of the population makes its money by doing so (or employing people who do so on their behalf), then that lost value disappears into their bank accounts, where it effectively doesn't exist. It does not circulate back into the economy. That is why this system requires infinite value; because value is depleted infinitely (over time), rather than created. 
I think that itself makes a very good case that this system that is our downfall is not Capitalism.
author: Stirgid Lanathiel

text:
¬†@Stirgid Lanathiel¬† Value is generated by labor. The simplistic, idealized model of capitalism you described doesn't exist, has never existed and never can. There's no such thing as an ideal free market or "pure capitalism", economic power is always combined with political power. Capitalism is the mode of production based on private ownership of the means of production. In practice this means capital being used to generate more capital, surplus value being extracted from exploited labor and market speculation.

What you described happening currently is correct but it's the inevitable and only logical conclusion of the capitalist market system. It can be no other way. Wealth accumulation from the bottom to the top inevitably creates a ruling class of privileged elites who control the state apparatus and maintain through violence or threat of violence their wealth, power and private property. Ultimately when applied on a global scale in its last stage capitalism becomes imperialism, which is the norm today.
author: Transsylvanian

text:
¬†@Transsylvanian¬† And I disagree; value is not created by labour, but by perception of worth of the product produced. Value is not an inherent or easily quantifiable trait. 


There is, indeed, no such thing as a 'pure capitalist market.' Not in a system where value is given quantifiable representation (money). However, 'capitalism' is not the same as 'pure free market.' As I have argued before. Capitalism can be maintained in a controlled market, and still be capitalist... And it can be overruled in an exploitative market, where value is lost to hoarders faster than it can be created.


Please understand that I am using the term 'capitalist' completely devoid of any political biases. I find that politics muddies the water and makes it impossible to fairly discuss these topics; we get so bogged down in tribalist competition that we forget about solving the issues at hand. Communism offers an alternative to capitalism, but communism in its purest form can only maintain an equilibrium of value at best, and a loss of value at worst. After all, if a labourer gets the same average for their effort as everybody else, even when they work harder, then to the labourer, value is lost and can only be regained by working less hard. (The same problem exists with wages that lie below the minimum living wage, which is a prominent feature of the USA's economic system).
Socialism, however, offers not so much alternatives to capitalism as safeguards against exploitation and corruption of capitalism. In order to keep the market free, it has to be controlled against the actions of bad players. There's many methods that can be employed, from imposed parameters to active government market undercutting (an example of which is Public Healthcare; the private sector isn't banned from participation, but everyone is ensured coverage at reasonable prices set by the competition of an undercutting Third Party agent, which is the government. Another example is China, whose government buys up farmed produce so that megacorporations cannot control, and thereby reduce, the agricultural options).


'Capitalism' is not a dirty word. It's just used the wrong way, used as an excuse by the NeoNobility to get away with what is essentially malpractice that hurts the economy.
author: Stirgid Lanathiel

text: ¬†@Stirgid Lanathiel¬† Economics can't be separated from politics because economy is politics and politics is economy at its core since its main object is the material wellbeing of society. Everything else in politics is a smokescreen. I disagree with your assertion that everyone has to be paid equally under communism and historical implementations also prove you wrong. Under Soviet socialism the more highly skilled (requiring higher education) or more dangerous labor was compensated better than average menial work, and excellence in the technical fields like math, engineering and science was encouraged and fostered by the educational system. In China during the cultural revolution when many people were organized into autonomous, self-managed collective communes, they set their own wages according to a democratic system of points awarded based on quality of work, difficulty, work hours, etc. they were not all paid equally but ownership was communal and management democratic and had a lot of worker participation, they would debate issues in local worker councils and express their opinions on the best course of action. This is what communism means, it's about collective ownership and workplace democracy. Private ownership automatically results in exploitation by those with means of production of those without. A market economy even when regulated will still be unstable and periodically crash, it will always lead to wealth accumulation and thereby accumulation of political power by a few elites, thus undermining democracy. Capitalism is inherently anti-democratic, companies are run in an undemocratic way and this seeps into the rest of a capitalist society.
author: Transsylvanian

text:
¬†@Transsylvanian¬† If different employees of the same corporate entity get paid differently (whether that entity be the State or the Commune), then Communism does not deliver equality, and is therefore not achieved. Collective ownership means nothing more than that every participant in the enterprise is an equal shareholder of said enterprise.
And no, the political and the economic are two different entities. They intersect, but they are not the same. The political exists to govern; either to serve or rule. The economical, however, is about resources. The political will influence the economic; either to serve or to exploit the populace, but they are functionally as different as a shepherd is functionally different from a sheep.

text:
¬†@Transsylvanian¬†... I wouldn't call current CO2 levels abnormally high.

If you look at it from a geological timescale, it's abnormally low. It has never been as low as it was just before the industrial revolution. I.e. Abound 284 ppm.

We increased it to 400ppm (which is scarily fast) 

CO levels have been 7000 pmm in the past. 

There has been several Ice Ages (including the Ice Age we are currently in...most people don't know this).... all of those ice ages came, went through their usual warm and cool cycles and ended, virtually unaffected by CO2. 

The earth is gonna experience rapid global cooling eventually. There's nothing we can do about it (it's a result of the earth's orbit changing periodically...due to Jupiter tugging at Earth periodically) 

When our orbit is more circular (as it is now), the earth experiences rapid global warming. When the orbit is more elliptical, rapid glabal cooling. (This happens under certain conditions, relating to ocean currents, which in turn is determined by things like the positions of continents) 

Even if we pumped 10 times more CO2 into the atmosphere, it won't stop rapid global cooling when Jupiter tugs us back into an elliptical orbit. 

That scenario existed in the past. During a previous Ice Age.

Also the ‚Äúlittle ice age‚Äù want an ice age. It was regional cooling in Europe. The global average didn‚Äôt change much. 
And those aren‚Äôt trends you saw. We know the glacial-interglacial cycles. Those are caused by Milankovitch cycles which depending on sunlight can effect the amount of CO2 in the air which warms/cools the earth. https://climate.nasa.gov/news/2948/milankovitch-orbital-cycles-and-their-role-in-earths-climate/

However this can‚Äôt explain he current warming. Global Temperatures have been very stable the last 11,000 years but now we are seeing a rapid warming. In fact just the last 35 years of rapid warming have canceled out the last 6,000 years of cooling. And we‚Äôre expecting a 4¬∞C to 5¬∞C warming by 2100. A warming not seen in 3 million years.

When Daniel Farenheit was developing the Farenheit scale, he set the lowest temperature he could create in his lab (-17.78¬∞C) as the base for the scale.

It makes much more sense starting it at absolute zero like the Kelvin scale does.

text: ¬†@Doco bonbon¬† It is climate change, yes, and I agree with just about all of Atlas Pro's dire predictions (with the proviso that both he and I could well be totally wrong; we'll just have to wait and see). But, as we're due for another ice age anyway (at least a minor one), I don't see the need to necessarily blame it all on human activity. I mean, it might be us, but it also could all be virtually 100% natural climate change that we would have gotten anyway even if we were still pre-industrial. Still, famine + fire & ice seem like a believable outcome that people on either side of the climate debate are really not going to like.

text: ¬†@Doco bonbon¬† I have no issue with erring on the side of caution (eg. I'm pro-solar but only as a bonus: it is too intermittent to rely on completely) when the costs are not too high: when policies are affordable, we may as well try not to make things worse 'just cause we can' but as we're either not really sure yet which way to jump we shouldn't pour all our resources into a solution which later turns out to be ineffective or - worse - is in fact wrong. text: I doubt the system would truly "shut down."  Heat at the equator and cold at the poles will cause currents.  Of greater concern would be a shift in how the currents flow or their rate of flow.  Go from the East Coast to the West Coast and you will see the difference of being on the "other side" of an ocean current.  East Coast is warmer because of the Gulf Stream, but the West Coast is much colder because it receives the currents after they've passed through colder regions.

author: Wesley Morgan

text:
It should be noted that during the medieval warm period and little ice age, the total world temperature average didn't shift all that much, beyond the very slow decline that had been happening for some thousands of years by then. Making it mostly a matter of heat redistribution back then, rather then the current case where the total amount of energy in the atmosphere is greatly increasing. 

So if the thermohaline cycle started seriously slowing or shut down, it would still be in the background of an on average warming world, which would probably substantially mitigate the total effect. Basically a bit like how northern Canada is getting warmer and warmer really. Obviously this means the tropics will only be even hellishly hotter yet though... so that's only getting worse I guess.

Still this larger world wide trend would probably make an ice age starting from the thermohaline slowing unlikely.

text:
7:30 there is actually some evidence of the Gulf Stream slowing down, maybe even stopping.
There are these microscopic sea life creatures called phorams that grow shells, to grow the shells they must get nutrients, normally, when the Gulf Stream is flowing most of these nutrients pass over the phorams and so they can't grow their shells as much (the shells become thin).
But if the Gulf Stream slows down, or even stops these nutrients will flow down to the seabed, so as a result the shells of these phorams will be thick.
So by looking at how thick/thin the shells of these phorams are and when they lived we can understand when they Gulf Stream has slowed down.
Sry for not including sources but im honeslty not too bothered and i should study.

text: The vocal audio seems to be changing rapidly between mono and left only. Since I'm guessing you record in mono with just one mic, this seems like a post production error. If you have any stereo wideners on your vocal, consider dropping them completely, since they don't really do anything for you. If this wasn't the case, most DAWs and audio processors will have a tool that sums to mono, by phasing out the sides. This can have a detrimental effect if you already have some sort of stereo processing, but if you use it on your vocal only, it shouldn't be a problem, and will effectively keep your vocal in mono all the way through.

text: So THIS is how your side is going to now try and explain the global cooling that is currently being driven by the grand solar minimum? First, there is absolutely zero evidence that human activity is a primary driver of climate change. In fact, we don't even have evidence we're in the top 10 driving forces. Our contributions to the yearly CO2 emissions (with all data we've managed to gather thus far) are less than 5% of the total of all CO2 emissions despite all claims to the contrary. Your side has tried to claim some sort of equilibrium was maintained before human activity and that we've thrown that off. Yet they can offer no supporting evidence to those claims. And because your side cannot prove a damn thing about their claims, they instead have to attack people telling the truth by calling them "deniers" evoking an emotional revulsion due to comparison to holocaust deniers. This tired old trope works and it chases away anyone who would shine a light on this unscientific blather.

text:
The problem, as I understand it, is that it doesn't matter how cold the arctic is if the circulation slows to a halt, since the preceding warm period means less water gets sent back south so it can go up north again. 'Cause it's a cycle, see?

I mean, seems like it would correct itself eventually, but we're talking very eventually. It's called an ice age for a reason. Keep in mind that the conservative estimate of the "little ice age" (which wasn't even a real one) is that it lasted three hundred years. This stuff happens really slowly and the trick is living through the interval.

text: Um Ah Um, No. Climate Change can not cause an ice age. Why?  An ice age is what happens when the climate changes. Ice ages are caused by the planets rotation around the sun and the tilt of the earths axis over a 48,000+ year time frame.  It is why there was an ice age 12,000 years ago that had just lasted 12,000  years long. There will be another Ice age form over the next 12,000 years. Then, 12,000 years from now. Ice a mile high will be covering Mich, NY, and NJ, in June. This will last for about 12,000 years when it will start to go back to today's temps over the next 12,000 years. THIS IS WHAT MAKES ICE AGES! We are trying to keep up with this 2 oct-trillion ton of burning plasma called THE SUN. Which is shooting threw space at an ave speed of 515,00 MPH. After a while the orbit of earth stretches and we spend most of the year farther away from then sun. Then the sun's OVER WHELMING gravity drags us slowly over 12,000 years back into a more circular orbit like we are today. This process takes about 48,000 years to complete and the earth's axis is changed 4 times during this time frame from a southern tip,  like we are in now, to a northern tip. This tipping is caused by the entropy of the earths electromagnetic shield. This is what caused the last ice age to make ice to be a mile deep in NY 12,000+ years ago. The northern hemisphere was tilted away from the sun for 12,000 years.  And our orbit was just ending a more elliptical pattern around the sun.  We are again now into 1,000 years of the earth going in a more elliptical orbit away from the sun. The temps should be going down but they are not. We should have continued the mini ice age. But the warming of 6 billion people has stop the earth from freezing are pants off. This may be an issue in the next 100 to 200 years... But, and listen carefully... 12,000 years from now? You are NOT going to be In NY, NJ, Or Mich, unless you are standing on an ICE sheet about a mile deep. And for most of that year? It will not be warm and the CLIMATE WILL BE CHANGING!  As to the mini ice age from 1300 to 1850. That is well documented that the Sun went into what is called a GRAND SOLAR MINIMUM during this time. Less pressure means colder temps. This is why we freeze during ice ages. We have less pressure from solar mass ejections hitting us most of the year when we are farther away in our yearly rotation around the sun. Less pressure from the sun on earths water vapor air and you get FREEZING WORLD WIDE TEMPS! To be clear. It is pressure from the sun that causes climate to change. Man may have warmed the planet. But nature will cool  them off no matter how much heat they produce. You are not going to out due the cold of space or the heat of the sun even if you used the whole mass of the earth. Stop with the fear mongering. It gets old. 10,000 feet above your head it is freezing right now even with the sun out full all day, why? PRESSURE!

text:
¬†@Matt TheChosen¬† The key point, however, is that those tribes have always been small. Lack of resources coupled with environmental harshness means that you cannot grow a civilization beyond the most basic tribal type.
Man currently has a population of 7.5 billion individuals.
author: Stirgid Lanathiel

text: ¬†@Stirgid Lanathiel¬† true, but they could survive back then with their limited resources. Today we can grow food anywhere on earth so long as we have power and water available. A nuclear power plant, a glacier or the ocean and a bunch of huge greenhouses like they use in Iceland, Israel and Spain and we would still have an oversupply of food, even if it is slightly more expensive than we are currently used to. Given we have known reserves of uranium to last over 40,000 years we could easily outlast an ice age and that's without all the other power sources we could utilise.
author: Matt TheChosen

text:
¬†@Matt TheChosen¬† The problem with that is resource collection. We have to build those facilities under such harsh conditions, extract resources under such harsh conditions, before we can benefit from that technology.
There's no doubt in my mind that humanity is going to survive another Ice Age (by human standards; not talking about polar ice cycles here), but the damage is going to be immense, and if any modicum of civilization survives, then that's purely because of knowledge and technology we were able to salvage.
Look at the Bronze Age collapse. Civilization itself fell apart; even literacy pretty much died out.
author: Stirgid Lanathiel

text: ¬†@Stirgid Lanathiel¬† how long a timeframe do u think it would be between realising an ice age was imminent and it being in full effect? Given the right incentives humanity can achieve insane projects really quickly, just look at things like the Apollo and Manhattan projects or the industrialization of both America and Europe around the second world war. Once a serious enough issue presents itself all the bickering goes out the window and progress becomes rapid. We could probably build enough infrastructure to both feed and house the entire worlds population around the equatorial regions within a decade if we really set out to do it. Of course we wouldn't, we would likely only provide for the people that are citizens of the wealthy nations, but civilization would survive just fine and could easily be maintained in the billions.
author: Matt TheChosen

text:
¬†@Matt TheChosen¬† I think by the time we know for sure, it's already been happening.
That being said: All attention will first and foremost go the the war effort as drought and heat drive mass migration and civil war.
In addition, sure, humans can do a lot in a little time... But the examples you gave, while technologically impressive, are very small in terms of population numbers. Quantity is a different factor than quality.


If humanity would set aside all of its differences and work as a single entity, then I think your ideas might work if we can act fast enough. As it stands, action will likely only be taken after it's already too late, and tribalist infighting between demographics will mean most people won't even make it to your arctic Hiver cities, much less participate in their creation.

text:
Oh yeah. One more thing. As saltwater around the poles get more fresh from the melting glaciers and ice sheets, the salinity will drop, which, will result in the water being able to freeze at a higher temperature (100% pure water freezes at 0 degrees celsius, obviously). Then the ice sheets will reflect alot of the sunlight back, and they will form a solid platform where snow can sit, which will reflect even more sunlight back. That will also cool down the earth even more. And as the gulf stream is weakened from the previous cooling of water from the ice being melted, the amount of warm water being able to hit the poles is reduced a lot, which also, will cool down the poles even more, to the point where sea water with higher salinity will freeze more easy because of the lower temperatures, which will create ice and do the same exact thing as I mentioned first. 


So in theory, the poles will get MUCH colder for a period, and the average temperature on high latitudes of the northern and southern hemisphere will also get colder. But the equator will heat up, because the warm water around there has nowhere to go as explained in the video, which in the end will reverse most of this (For a period). 


I am located in Denmark btw, and another thing about why Europe is on average much warmer than America, is because we have sea (Island) climate, instead of continental climate (like the USA has). The sea around Europe, (Which is also warmer than that of the USA at same latitudes), will cool down the land in the summer, but heat it up in the winter. Oh yeah and the main mountain ranges here in Europe are also mostly running from west to east (Alps, pyrenees, dinarian alps, scottish highlands, and some parts of the scandinavian mountains), which will block the amount of cold air being transferred from the poles, to mainland Europe because of pressure systems building up on the north side of the mountains. That also explains why we usually get the coldest cold fronts from the east (Siberia/ Russia), and not from the Scandinavian peninsula (We also get cold fronts from there, or Denmark does atleast). Oh yeah and the average altitude in continental north Europe (North of the alps, south of the Scaninavian Peninsula) here is also a bit lower than the US.


I am not a scientist. I have just been thinking a lot of this, and been using common knowledge and sense. 


Forgot to mention a thing. It would be really nice if tou could please leave a like. I spent a lot of time on this comment, and it would be kinda sad to see it getting lost in the comments. Oh another thing. Sorry if my grammar is a bit off, since my main language is Danish, and I'm soon 16 years old, with about 6-7 years of learning English at school. Have a nice day :)

text: Very few of the actual outcomes of Global Warming are in and of themselves strictly undesirable. Less rainwater means less flooding, unless you weren't afraid of that in the first place. More rainwater means cheaper water, unless it's already free because you get too much. Warmer temperatures means shorter winters, i.e. longer growing seasons. The problem is that the biosphere prefers to have a few centuries to adapt to change and we're already straining many species, many of which we already strained past what they could adapt much faster than what we generally see in the fossil record outside of extinction events. We tend to like the biosphere for the most part and don't particularly care to find out how much of it we can remove before we have to start supporting ourselves biologically. In addition, different weather patterns means that we're going to have to change our infrastructure all over the world to deal with whatever the new climates become. You start having more droughts, that means more water storage in reservoirs. More flooding, better drainage, and perhaps the need to construct large pipes that take excess water to the places with droughts. More storms, better methods of dealing with them so you don't have a refugee crisis on the coasts every storm season. All of that is expensive, and especially for poorer nations, they're just going to have to change their lifestyle to cope while richer nations like America are going to need to deal with higher costs associated with living the way we want to where we want to. Now personally, I think that some of these solutions should be undertaken even if Global Warming weren't a thing. Honestly, it's pitiful how poorly we deal with major storms that hit cities. But yea, the story of Global Warming for the most part is, we know that temperatures on average are going to rise, and we're not seeing too many positive outcomes and plenty detrimental ones, but exact effects on places are still subject to many things we are less certain about. In a way it's like the fact that we can understand how the universe is likely to end despite the fact that predicting human society past a few decades is currently impossible as there are way too many potential technologies each of which could have major effects on society.

text: Banana Well that depends on where and when and to what degree Global Warming gets to, and I‚Äôm not saying that things won‚Äôt be bad, it‚Äôs going to be far more than an inconvenience for many places and plenty of places will have very different amounts of rainfall that will result in many long-term changes, just that I doubt that we‚Äôll let it affect us too much. For example, the logical thing to do would be to move away from places where water becomes rarer as water prices gets more expensive. But if that were the case, places like Phoenix would have never been inhabited. It‚Äôs going to be costly, and for poorer nations deadly, but I have yet to hear anything reliable about it being catastrophic. So don‚Äôt take what I‚Äôm saying as it‚Äôll be just an inconvenience we‚Äôll get over, I‚Äôm indicating major infrastructural changes around the globe to deal with new weather patterns, the loss of plenty of species and ecosystems we wanted. Afterall, the Great-Reef is pretty much already dead. I do think that humans will adapt one way or another, but that‚Äôs because we tend to be able to adapt to anything, including being enslaved, and while the Climate will be changing too rapidly for many species to biologically adapt, only the absolute worst cases such as Europe being caught in a cold snap and never preparing for it (which considering debating the existence of Climate Change isn‚Äôt political over there, seems unlikely they wouldn‚Äôt prepare at some point) would Climate change result in changes too rapid for human societies to adapt.
author: Treviisolion

text:
I'm Australian, our 'normal' weather cycle is already what most people worry climate change might bring. Honestly people just adapt to it, it's no big deal after awhile. We have some of the worst drought areas in the world yet some of the biggest rain/cyclone events that can cause floods so bad that towns can turn into islands for weeks at a time. We have severe bushfires that make California's look like a camp campfire. We have can have fires in one part of the country, snow in another, drought in another and flooding in another all at the same time, but that's just life here. Honestly l don't think many people really realise just how adaptable humans can be if they need to be, we will simply find a way. 
Of course Australians by global rates are essentially rich as hell on average (one of, if not the highest average net wealth per person) so we can afford to do whatever is needed, but we got this wealthy by being adaptable and working with what we had(oh and a shit ton of pretty much every natural resource imaginable).

author: replica

text: replica I‚Äôm well aware that humans are raising the temperature at an unprecedented pace, I have not claimed otherwise. There have been a few periods in which the world could have been ice free for a few thousand years, but I have not found any indication that we know for certain. Those were periods where either global temperatures and CO2 concentrations were well above current levels, or the geography lended to a very smooth global temperature with the poles not being much colder than the tropics. Examples include parts of the Cambrian, Ordovician, Cambrian, and Cretaceous. CO2 concentrations in those times were anywhere from 800 ppm to 4400 ppm. The only one that seems reasonable for humans to reach is the lower 800 ppm. I also have yet to see any reliable source saying the glaciers will take any less than several thousand years to melt even if it gets warm enough all of them will (which I also haven‚Äôt seen, rather that they‚Äôll be greatly reduced and reach an equilibrium with much less area covered under worst cases). I‚Äôm not certain why you bring up solar wind as oxygen and carbon are trace elements in them, the amount of solar wind itself is fairly minuscule itself on the timelines we talk about when talking about Global Warming and what we can do about it, and it‚Äôs pretty reduced by our magnetic field, so feel free to illustrate why you brought it up. The increased tectonic activity is new that I hadn‚Äôt heard of before, though the principle makes sense. Doing a quick search is bringing only a few studies, so hopefully we can research this more so we can better determine the exact effects. That said, your solution of producing no heat is unfortunately not a solution. Humans themselves produce waste heat, and killing ourselves would doom Earth to burn in about 900 million years when the planet is cooked by our aging sun. My original point, is that exact future effects of Global Warming are still not 100% certain, but they generally aren‚Äôt good, and that we need to find ways to deal with them especially as many of them we‚Äôd have to deal with anyways even without Global Warming (hurricanes have been around for much longer than we‚Äôve had to worry about Global Warming, and even if we solve Global Warming that doesn‚Äôt solve Hurricanes still occasionally coming and destroying coastal cities). Furthermore the point is that humans will adapt. That‚Äôs not necessarily a good thing. Humans will adapt to any situation, good or bad. Prevent what we can, fix what we can‚Äôt, and Mitigate the rest. Ultimately though, the reason why we‚Äôve decided Global Warming is bad, is because it harms people. The easiest solution would be to create a virus that kills off all of humanity, but in that context then Global Warming is no longer a problem, it‚Äôs just a weird tiny blip on the Earth‚Äôs paleoclimate. For anyone else who has read to this point: If you are saying that Global Warming will end humanity then I call bullshit. If you are not and think that I‚Äôm understating Global Warming, then I feel the statement Millions will die doesn‚Äôt apparently mean anything. If you think my understanding is fundamentally flawed, then provide a link to a reliable source or reference easily searchable things, and forgive me but I doubt a Climate Scientist will be debating a random person on YouTube about how Global Warming works.
author: Treviisolion

text: replica Also are you referencing any other Global temperature mechanics other than lowering albedo means more heat absorbed by the sun thus taking us closer to black body temperatures while increased CO2 concentrations and other greenhouse gases increase the amount of heat that would otherwise be radiated away being trapped thus increasing temperatures that way? Because I do understand those and have yet to see any evidence for them to not be true, ie. as far as I know they‚Äôre actual mechanics that we‚Äôre having measurable effects on that is in turn resulting in a higher temperature which in turn is affecting various other systems. If you know of something else, then do please share it, just don‚Äôt be an ass with a holier than thou perspective that just says to do more research when you are almost certainly not a Climate Scientist yourself and thus are also learning about all this second-hand at best. If you got actual studies, then I‚Äôll be happy to see them, meanwhile if you want you can read the latest IPCC report which reports on Climate data and what we know and how certain we are we know it. Btw, projections are at most going to have at about 1 meter of sea rise by 2100, estimates are that if all the ice melted that‚Äôs 30 meters. If we haven‚Äôt learned to deal with Global Warming by then, then there‚Äôs really not much hope for humanity as apparently we will just have stopped solving problems at that point.

author: replica

text:
replica yes, everything absorbs heat. That‚Äôs basic physics everyone should learn in Highschool if not sooner. You appear to be predicting that we‚Äôre in large danger of turning Earth into a second Venus (or to at least produce a climate never seen before when actual reports are that we‚Äôre producing a climate not seen for millions of years, not never), and well, I have seen no credible source indicating either of those except yours, and forgive me, but your credentials of random YouTube commenter don‚Äôt exactly lead me to believe you over the majority of Climate Scientists. Also I did the math, assuming that the Sun has radiated about 5 billion kg of mass per second for the last billion years, that any mass headed our way was able to make the entire journey, and that the magnetosphere hasn‚Äôt blocked any of the heavier elements that reached us, and that a whopping .1% of all solar wind is carbon and oxygen in the right amounts to produce carbon dioxide (2 oxygen atoms for every carbon atom as apparently we‚Äôre specifying stupidly obvious stuff), then we‚Äôre talking about 600 metric tons over the course of a billion years. Let‚Äôs say that I seriously lowballed it and round it to 10,000 metric tons. That sounds like a lot, until you realize that the total amount of CO2 in the atmosphere weighs about 3 trillion metric tons. Now I am just a random YouTube commentator so it‚Äôs certainly possible I did my calculations wrong especially as they were fairly back of hand stuff. And if you got even an article or something that backs up the idea that we‚Äôre gaining enough carbon and oxygen to make any real dent over any scales other than the largest of geological then that‚Äôll be interesting, but so far it doesn‚Äôt seem we‚Äôll be hitting even 1000 ppm CO2 concentrations, when Earth has had a whopping 4400 ppm CO2 concentrations during the Cambrian era. That‚Äôs not to say it isn‚Äôt a problem, but Earth will survive, it‚Äôs a big uncaring rock orbiting an uncaring sun, that will kill us all if we let it in a measly 900 million years, in a vast uncaring universe that does not care because it isn‚Äôt intelligent or even alive. The Earth will stay that same orbiting rock, until the Sun engulfs it or goes SuperNova. The life on it unless we blow up the surface with nukes, will still be going until photosynthesis fails in 900 million years when temperatures are expected to rise to such a degree (from the sun‚Äôs expansion and increased luminosity as it ages, not humans at that point), and we‚Äôre talking 50 to several hundred of degrees warmer, with current projections of what humans are likely to cause generally maxing out at 4 degrees celsius under almost unrealistically bad worst case scenarios (we‚Äôre currently looking at more likely 2 degrees). Until you have anybody to corroborate your claims, good day. And perhaps you should do some research, and maybe start with the IPCC and their reports as they‚Äôre the ones tasked with summarizing all the data we‚Äôve gathered, presenting it in such unambiguous terms, they‚Äôve provided a list of percentages that correspond with specific phrases, and indicate everything from how certain we are that Global Warming is real, whether it‚Äôs primarily of Anthropogenic origin, and what the likely effects are going to be as well as what we can do to mitigate it and prevent it, as well as what we‚Äôll need to do to adapt in the cases where we don‚Äôt. 

I also want to say, that not all your suggestions on stopping Global Warming are terrible, just that you seem to have some crazy theories I have no idea from where you got them, and I‚Äôm done with this conversation unless it‚Äôll actually result in something actually productive instead of us having to pride ourselves on knowing basic physics that anyone who wants to discuss Global Warming should be aware of.

author: Scepnex

text:
¬†@MrAranton¬† But those tie back to the complexity of the EU as an organisation - again, I'm a remainer and, honestly, a European Federalist, so I'm not bashing the EU for this, but no withdrawal agreement (and by my understanding, the agreement is pretty vague on a lot of topics, it's basically a politically-convenient postponment of all the tough decisions) could ever be fully comprehended by, let alone satisfy, an electorate or a majority of MPs. Especially when it comes to the Northern Irish border.

The current quagmire of indecision was a 100% inevitable after the vote decision. The same thing would have happened if it had been Spain or the Netherlands or anywhere else trying to leave (and actually, it would have been worse, given that most other countries are in Schengen and the Eurozone). The EU is, by its nature, a hard institution to leave.
author: Merry Machiavelli

text:
¬†@Merry Machiavelli¬† 
The time to discuss and decide most of the issues the various factions have with the separation agreement, would have been before article 50 was triggered. It was madness to go into the negotions with no idea what the country wants to get out of the separation agreement. Decisions like soft brexit or hard brexit or how to deal with Northern Ireland, should have been made before the negotiations started. But since these issues were not settlend within the UK, they couldn't possibly be settled in the separation agreement. And when Theresa May finally defined a position (the Chequers-Plan) - one and a half years late - she lost about half her cabinet. It's as though someone went to a car-dealership to negotiate a lease with no clues whether he (or she) wants to lease a car, a lorry or a tractor. Had the UK government done this properly and defined its goal before it started the process, the UK wouldn't be in that "quagmire of indecision" now.


When the negotiations started, Michel Barnier complained publically how poorly the british delegation was prepared, how little interest his the counterpart David Davis seemed to take (the man couldn't even be bothered to be present the entire time) and that the delegations leaders didn't seem to understand the consequences of their positions. Davis is a brexit hardliner and in retrospect it seems he wasn't negotiating in good faith but deliberately sabotaging the negotations to make sure there wouldn't be a successful separation agreement, thus guarantueeing a diamond hard brexit.  Having someone oversee the negotiations of the separation agreement who wants to cut all ties and doesn't understand why a separation agreement is needed in the first place was a royally stupid move.
Neither of those issues have anything to do with how complex the matter is. They have to do with infighting due to poor leadership and the failure to make decisions when they needed to be made. The EU has gone out of its way to protect the British people from the idiocy of their leaders.


I'm not sure about Spain. But the Netherlands were a founding member of the predecessor organizations of the EU. They have plenty of experience with multilateral negotiations and coming to a consensus within their own country. The fact that Netherlands didn't have a global empire from which draw delusions of grandeur that led lots of Brits to believe the EU would be a pushover and the UK everything they want. So I'm pretty sure, if they had decided to leave the EU they would have known that there was plenty to discuss and decide before article 50 is triggered.
The issue there is: British political culture is based on competition and a "winner takes it all" approach which is fundamentally incompatible with the more consensus-oriented politcal culture on the continent. British politicians are not used to compromise; most of them see compromise as a sign of weakness and failure.
author: MrAranton

text: ¬†@MrAranton¬† TBH I'm not really interested in having a debate with somebody who has made their mind up about Britains general shit-ness (Playing the patriot is not my style). That said, the old 'Britain is being nostalgic about its empire' line is one I have heard from non-British Europeans over and over again. I get it, for most of the world the image of Britain as a (now-ex) imperial power was the single defining trait of the country for centuries - how could a major IR decision be unrelated to it? But, surprise surprise, political discourse has kinda moved on and the average person the street never felt close to Empire anyway. It's crude cultural essentialism. But hey, the Germans are still Nazis, the Scandinavians are still Vikings and the French have another Revolution right around the corner, right?
author: Merry Machiavelli

text:
¬†@Merry Machiavelli¬† You're responding to generalizations I didn't intend to make. I wasn't talking about all Brits, but Brexiters or even more particularly those people in government who felt they could get away with half-assed negotiations. Whether you like it or not: Brexiters did make arguments based on post imperial delusions of grandeur - like "The EU needs Britain (and access to its market) more than the other way around, so desperately the UK will be able to dictate terms and get all the benefits of EU membership with none of the resposibilities" or "once the UK leaves the Britain will be able to negotiate trade deals with the entire world - as though the entire world just waited for that and would make getting a trade agreement with 65 million consumer Britain their top priority..." And enough people bought into that crap to give "leave" a majority. Though, granted; It's possible there were people who voted leave just to give Cameron the finger, not because they actually wanted to leave the EU. We both know how close the referndum was and that almost half the population didn't buy into into the nationalistic "better off alone" rhetoric - at least not enough to actually vote "leave". I thought that was so obvious it didn't need mentioning.
The point I was trying to make is a very different one: The people in Britain should be aware how badly the government bungled the process and not let them evade the consequences because "leaving the EU is hard". Even with the hardest task there's a difference between failing honourably after giving your best and failing miserably by neglecting even the most basic aspects.
author: MrAranton

text: This video is so full of holes and lies. We are currently in an ice age. Namely Quaternary Ice age for the last 5 million years. Temperatures in Greenland dropped because of the 2 meteorites,  found in the last year, that hit earth around 12,800 years ago. The medieval warm period was warmer than now, say over 100 studies here https://wattsupwiththat.com/2018/02/12/more-evidence-that-the-medieval-warming-period-was-global-not-regional/. The little ice age was colder than 95% of the last 10,000 years. Ice ages happen ever 150 million years or so when the solar system crosses milky way's spiral arms. The glaciations, like the last one of 15,000 years ago happen every 100,000 years and this interglacial we're in (warm period) is due. I'm appalled how someone can mislead so many and still profit.

author: Dean Andrew MacInnes

text:
¬†@Dean Andrew MacInnes¬† The level of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased from 260 ppm (parts per million) in 1800 to 420ppm in 2020, that's an increase of 58% in 220 years. Do you want to know what happened the last time that drastic an increase occurred? There was a mass extinction event. The time before that? Another mass extinction event. In fact the only time in the history of Earth that there has been a more sudden increase in CO2 levels in Earths history was after the eruption of a mega volcano that caused the largest extinction event in the planets history, The Great Dying/Permian extinction, which wiped out 98% of all life on Earth including all advanced land based life forms. The natural cycles that you refer to saw CO2 vary between 180ppm and 300ppm.

It seems we have a rather different definition of what constitutes a serious shift in the atmosphere composition.

Besides all of that even if you take climate change out of the debate entirely a shift towards renewable and clean energy is the logical option. I'm sure you don't like having polluted air to breath and water to drink do you? How about sea life, I doubt you want that to get wiped out by overfishing and dumping plastic into the ocean? Or forests, do you like those? Well if you do then you should support clean energy and sustainable farming.

Simply put there is no cohesive argument against clean energy and a more sustainable use of the planets resources even if you dismiss climate change. You have no leg to stand on here.
author: ddandymann

text:
¬†@ddandymann¬†  Looks to me like a copy and paste job... At least a copied job, but OK.... The fact that it already happened without humans (Multiple times...... More times than we probably know and before extinction event's actually happened) begs the question "is it us doing this". My point isn't that co2 is not building up, but that there's cycles which allow for co2 to be released at a higher rate. The fact that our planet is warming because of the sun, allows for more vegetative growth and so more co2 to be released........ And that cycle goes on and on until it doesn't and all hell breaks loose. Cycles of the sun have a far bigger impact on our global climate than the use of and release of carbon by humans. You're taking that whole number and blaming it on humans when there is far more at work than just humans on our planet. Whats above us and below us counts too. You mention that the last time there was a drastic change in the amount of co2 being released was because of an eruption - but failed to mention that said eruption caused 100,000 Billion tons of co2 to be released in a short period of time(which is what in ppm??(Parts Per Million)).  Obviously very deadly. Comparing what we do (with incorrect information) and that eruption is of a very impudent manner. 



It seems that way because it most definitely is that way. 

As you may have seen, the renewable energy sector has taken a hit throughout this winter and will continue to do so as the world gets colder. Deforestation isn't even happening on that big of a scale taking into consideration how big our world is and how many trees/forest's and all different kinds of plant life there is. Once upon a time (during human times) The Sahara was green. How big are Russian forest's? African? South American? American? European? How many trees and forests do they all have that are untouched. The world changes and so do facts..... Cycles on the other hand, they have proven to be continuously persistent. HOWEVER..... I do agree about plastic in our oceans and over-fishing which steps have been taken and laws put in place to minimize this, so that isn't even a part of this conversation right here. You've gone right off track. And how we deal with fossil fuels and natural gasses needs attending to, I agree. There have been unforgivable mistakes that have taken place and will continue to do so if we don't have pipelines and other means of transport for these goods. I say, we should use both energies (nonrenewable and renewable) to the best of our capabilities. 

P.s, I have two legs to stand on.

text:
That part is a circulation, though. Natural processes producing CO2 are balanced out by natural processes removing CO2 from the atmosphere, more or less.
What we're doing (and have been doing for the last one and a half century) is taking a lot of carbon out of the ground and blowing it into the atmosphere as CO2, i.e. adding CO2 into the circulation.
So it's not the absolute percentage of CO2 that humans produce, it's that basically all of the rise in the atmospheric levels of CO2 is due to human activity. This has been mitigated a bit by additional absorption of oceans and plant life but not nearly enough.

text: ¬†@Colin Watson¬† The Gulf Stream is driven by the trade winds and technically starts off the west coast of Africa at the equator.   It gets confined by the South American continental shelf and then the Gulf of Mexico continental shelf and then flows north.  It starts with the equatorial trade winds (blowing east to west) and the rotation of the Earth.  The return system starts under the sea ice in the Arctic ocean where it sinks and stays in each Arctic ocean basin for 400 years or so.  Then it finally flows over the choke points out in the north Atlantic (at the very bottom bottom because it is the most dense water there is on the planet) and it flows all the way to the south Atlantic where it runs into the Antarctic bottom water and slowly surfaces somewhere in the south Atlantic.  So stop the winds, stp the rotation of the Earth, stop the 180 days of darkness in the Arctic, tilt the Earth differently and you can stop the AMOC.  In other words, this has not happened in 4.4 billion years.

text:
That is exactly what it means. We already have the infrastructure to handle extreme cold. We would be better off than almost every other state minus Alaska and maybe... maybe Colorado. Don't forget skywalks between buildings and insulation meant for -60 degrees Fahrenheit (-51 degrees Celsius). We're already prepared. If you go down south, like Arizona or Mississippi, they will¬†literally break down over 1 inch of snow and 32 degrees. Minnesota would become more dominant because we would sell skill and product for insulation, infrastructure regulations, and so forth. I'm not saying we would take over the world, but we would be a more dominant state. 

Also you're acting like Northern Canada like conditions¬†means an unlivable hell scape. It doesn't, it just means greater expenditures on infrastructure and more green houses with a higher emphasis on the agricultural sciences like¬†The Netherlands has been doing.
author: Isaiah Young
